function.name: gdk_content_provider_write_mime_type_finish
function.description:
Finishes an asynchronous write operation.
See [method@Gdk.ContentProvider.write_mime_type_async].

parameter.name: error
parameter.parameter_description: a `GError` location to store the error occurring

function.return: %TRUE if the operation was completed successfully. Otherwise @error will be set to describe the failure.

function.name: gdk_content_register_deserializer
function.description: Registers a function to deserialize object of a given type.

parameter.name: mime_type
parameter.parameter_description: the mime type which the function can deserialize from

parameter.name: type
parameter.parameter_description: the type of objects that the function creates

function.name: gdk_content_register_serializer
function.description: Registers a function to serialize objects of a given type.

parameter.name: type
parameter.parameter_description: the type of objects that the function can serialize

parameter.name: mime_type
parameter.parameter_description: the mime type to serialize to

function.name: gdk_content_serialize_async
function.description:
Serialize content and write it to the given output stream, asynchronously.
The default I/O priority is %G_PRIORITY_DEFAULT (i.e. 0), and lower numbers indicate a higher priority.

parameter.name: stream
parameter.parameter_description: a `GOutputStream` to write the serialized content to

parameter.name: mime_type
parameter.parameter_description: the mime type to serialize to

parameter.name: io_priority
parameter.parameter_description: the I/O priority of the operation

parameter.name: callback
parameter.parameter_description: callback to call when the operation is done

parameter.name: user_data
parameter.parameter_description: data to pass to the callback function

function.name: gdk_content_serialize_finish
function.description: Finishes a content serialization operation.
function.return: %TRUE if the operation was successful, %FALSE if an error occurred. In this case, @error is set

function.name: gdk_content_serializer_get_cancellable
function.description:
Gets the cancellable for the current operation.
This is the `GCancellable` that was passed to [func@content_serialize_async].
function.return: the cancellable for the current operation

function.name: gdk_content_serializer_get_gtype
function.description: Gets the `GType` to of the object to serialize.

function.name: gdk_content_serializer_get_mime_type
function.description: Gets the mime type to serialize to.
function.return: the mime type for the current operation

function.name: gdk_content_serializer_get_output_stream
function.description:
Gets the output stream for the current operation.
This is the stream that was passed to [func@content_serialize_async].
function.return: the output stream for the current operation

function.name: gdk_content_serializer_get_priority
function.description:
Gets the I/O priority for the current operation.
This is the priority that was passed to [func@content_serialize_async].
function.return: the I/O priority for the current operation

function.name: gdk_content_serializer_get_task_data
function.description:
Gets the data that was associated with the current operation.
See [method@Gdk.ContentSerializer.set_task_data].

function.name: gdk_content_serializer_get_user_data
function.description: Gets the user data that was passed when the serializer was registered.
function.return: the user data for this serializer

function.name: gdk_content_serializer_get_value
function.description: Gets the `GValue` to read the object to serialize from.

function.name: gdk_content_serializer_return_error
function.description:
Indicate that the serialization has ended with an error.
This function consumes @error.

function.name: gdk_content_serializer_return_success
function.description: Indicate that the serialization has been successfully completed.

function.name: gdk_content_serializer_set_task_data
function.description: Associate data with the current serialization operation.

parameter.name: data
parameter.parameter_description: data to associate with this operation

function.name: gdk_crossing_event_get_detail
function.description: Extracts the notify detail from a crossing event.

function.name: gdk_crossing_event_get_focus
function.description: Checks if the @event surface is the focus surface.
function.return: %TRUE if the surface is the focus surface

function.name: gdk_crossing_event_get_mode
function.description: Extracts the crossing mode from a crossing event.

function.name: gdk_cursor_get_fallback
function.description:
Returns the fallback for this @cursor.
The fallback will be used if this cursor is not available on a given `GdkDisplay`. For named cursors, this can happen when using nonstandard names or when using an incomplete cursor theme. For textured cursors, this can happen when the texture is too large or when the `GdkDisplay` it is used on does not support textured cursors.
function.return: the fallback of the cursor or %NULL to use the default cursor as fallback

function.name: gdk_cursor_get_hotspot_x
function.description:
Returns the horizontal offset of the hotspot.
The hotspot indicates the pixel that will be directly above the cursor.
Note that named cursors may have a nonzero hotspot, but this function will only return the hotspot position for cursors created with [ctor@Gdk.Cursor.new_from_texture].
function.return: the horizontal offset of the hotspot or 0 for named cursors

function.name: gdk_cursor_get_hotspot_y
function.description:
Returns the vertical offset of the hotspot.
The hotspot indicates the pixel that will be directly above the cursor.
Note that named cursors may have a nonzero hotspot, but this function will only return the hotspot position for cursors created with [ctor@Gdk.Cursor.new_from_texture].
function.return: the vertical offset of the hotspot or 0 for named cursors

function.name: gdk_cursor_get_name
function.description:
Returns the name of the cursor.
If the cursor is not a named cursor, %NULL will be returned.
function.return: the name of the cursor or %NULL if it is not a named cursor

function.name: gdk_cursor_get_texture
function.description:
Returns the texture for the cursor.
If the cursor is a named cursor, %NULL will be returned.
function.return: the texture for cursor or %NULL if it is a named cursor

function.name: gdk_cursor_new_from_callback
function.description:
Creates a new callback-based cursor object.
Cursors of this kind produce textures for the cursor image on demand, when the @callback is called.
Since: 4.16

parameter.name: fallback
parameter.parameter_description: the `GdkCursor` to fall back to when this one cannot be supported

function.name: gdk_cursor_new_from_name
function.description:
Creates a new cursor by looking up @name in the current cursor theme.
A recommended set of cursor names that will work across different platforms can be found in the CSS specification:
| | | | | | --- | --- | ---- | --- | | "none" | ![](default_cursor.png) "default" | ![](help_cursor.png) "help" | ![](pointer_cursor.png) "pointer" | | ![](context_menu_cursor.png) "context-menu" | ![](progress_cursor.png) "progress" | ![](wait_cursor.png) "wait" | ![](cell_cursor.png) "cell" | | ![](crosshair_cursor.png) "crosshair" | ![](text_cursor.png) "text" | ![](vertical_text_cursor.png) "vertical-text" | ![](alias_cursor.png) "alias" | | ![](copy_cursor.png) "copy" | ![](no_drop_cursor.png) "no-drop" | ![](move_cursor.png) "move" | ![](not_allowed_cursor.png) "not-allowed" | | ![](grab_cursor.png) "grab" | ![](grabbing_cursor.png) "grabbing" | ![](all_scroll_cursor.png) "all-scroll" | ![](col_resize_cursor.png) "col-resize" | | ![](row_resize_cursor.png) "row-resize" | ![](n_resize_cursor.png) "n-resize" | ![](e_resize_cursor.png) "e-resize" | ![](s_resize_cursor.png) "s-resize" | | ![](w_resize_cursor.png) "w-resize" | ![](ne_resize_cursor.png) "ne-resize" | ![](nw_resize_cursor.png) "nw-resize" | ![](sw_resize_cursor.png) "sw-resize" | | ![](se_resize_cursor.png) "se-resize" | ![](ew_resize_cursor.png) "ew-resize" | ![](ns_resize_cursor.png) "ns-resize" | ![](nesw_resize_cursor.png) "nesw-resize" | | ![](nwse_resize_cursor.png) "nwse-resize" | ![](zoom_in_cursor.png) "zoom-in" | ![](zoom_out_cursor.png) "zoom-out" | |

parameter.name: fallback
parameter.parameter_description: %NULL or the `GdkCursor` to fall back to when this one cannot be supported

function.return: a new `GdkCursor`, or %NULL if there is no cursor with the given name

function.name: gdk_cursor_new_from_texture
function.description: Creates a new cursor from a `GdkTexture`.

parameter.name: texture
parameter.parameter_description: the texture providing the pixel data

parameter.name: hotspot_x
parameter.parameter_description: the horizontal offset of the “hotspot” of the cursor

parameter.name: hotspot_y
parameter.parameter_description: the vertical offset of the “hotspot” of the cursor

parameter.name: fallback
parameter.parameter_description: the `GdkCursor` to fall back to when this one cannot be supported

function.name: gdk_device_get_axis_use
function.description: Returns the axis use for @index_.
function.return: a `GdkAxisUse` specifying how the axis is used.

function.name: gdk_device_get_caps_lock_state
function.description:
Retrieves whether the Caps Lock modifier of the keyboard is locked.
This is only relevant for keyboard devices.
function.return: %TRUE if Caps Lock is on for @device

function.name: gdk_device_get_device_tool
function.description: Retrieves the current tool for @device.

function.name: gdk_device_get_direction
function.description:
Returns the direction of effective layout of the keyboard.
This is only relevant for keyboard devices.
The direction of a layout is the direction of the majority of its symbols. See [func@Pango.unichar_direction].
function.return: %PANGO_DIRECTION_LTR or %PANGO_DIRECTION_RTL if it can determine the direction. %PANGO_DIRECTION_NEUTRAL otherwise

function.name: gdk_device_get_display
function.description: Returns the `GdkDisplay` to which @device pertains.

function.name: gdk_device_get_has_cursor
function.description:
Determines whether the pointer follows device motion.
This is not meaningful for keyboard devices, which don't have a pointer.
function.return: %TRUE if the pointer follows device motion

function.name: gdk_device_get_modifier_state
function.description:
Retrieves the current modifier state of the keyboard.
This is only relevant for keyboard devices.

function.name: gdk_device_get_name
function.description: The name of the device, suitable for showing in a user interface.

function.name: gdk_device_get_num_lock_state
function.description:
Retrieves whether the Num Lock modifier of the keyboard is locked.
This is only relevant for keyboard devices.
function.return: %TRUE if Num Lock is on for @device

function.name: gdk_device_get_num_touches
function.description: Retrieves the number of touch points associated to @device.

function.name: gdk_device_get_product_id
function.description:
Returns the product ID of this device.
This ID is retrieved from the device, and does not change. See [method@Gdk.Device.get_vendor_id] for more information.

function.name: gdk_device_get_scroll_lock_state
function.description:
Retrieves whether the Scroll Lock modifier of the keyboard is locked.
This is only relevant for keyboard devices.
function.return: %TRUE if Scroll Lock is on for @device

function.name: gdk_device_get_seat
function.description: Returns the `GdkSeat` the device belongs to.

function.name: gdk_device_get_source
function.description: Determines the type of the device.

function.name: gdk_device_get_surface_at_position
function.description: Obtains the surface underneath @device, returning the location of the device in @win_x and @win_y.

parameter.name: win_x
parameter.parameter_description: return location for the X coordinate of the device location relative to the surface origin

parameter.name: win_y
parameter.parameter_description: return location for the Y coordinate of the device location relative to the surface origin

function.name: gdk_device_get_timestamp
function.description:
Returns the timestamp of the last activity for this device.
In practice, this means the timestamp of the last event that was received from the OS for this device. (GTK may occasionally produce events for a device that are not received from the OS, and will not update the timestamp).
Since: 4.2
function.return: the timestamp of the last activity for this device

function.name: gdk_device_get_vendor_id
gdk_device_has_bidi_layouts
function.description:
Determines if layouts for both right-to-left and left-to-right languages are in use on the keyboard.
This is only relevant for keyboard devices.
function.return: %TRUE if there are layouts with both directions, %FALSE otherwise

function.name: gdk_device_pad_get_feature_group
function.description:
Returns the group the given @feature and @idx belong to.
f the feature or index do not exist in @pad, -1 is returned.

parameter.name: feature
parameter.parameter_description: the feature type to get the group from

parameter.name: feature_idx
parameter.parameter_description: the index of the feature to get the group from

function.return: The group number of the queried pad feature.

function.name: gdk_device_pad_get_group_n_modes
function.description: Returns the number of modes that @group may have.

parameter.name: group_idx
parameter.parameter_description: group to get the number of available modes from

function.return: The number of modes available in @group.

function.name: gdk_device_pad_get_n_features
function.description: Returns the number of features a tablet pad has.
function.return: The amount of elements of type @feature that this pad has.

function.name: gdk_device_pad_get_n_groups
function.description:
Returns the number of groups this pad device has.
Pads have at least one group. A pad group is a subcollection of buttons/strip/rings that is affected collectively by a same current mode.
function.return: The number of button/ring/strip groups in the pad.

function.name: gdk_device_tool_get_axes
function.description: Gets the axes of the tool.

function.name: gdk_device_tool_get_hardware_id
function.description:
Gets the hardware ID of this tool, or 0 if it's not known.
When non-zero, the identifier is unique for the given tool model, meaning that two identical tools will share the same @hardware_id, but will have different serial numbers (see [method@Gdk.DeviceTool.get_serial]).
This is a more concrete (and device specific) method to identify a `GdkDeviceTool` than [method@Gdk.DeviceTool.get_tool_type], as a tablet may support multiple devices with the same `GdkDeviceToolType`, but different hardware identifiers.
function.return: The hardware identifier of this tool.

function.name: gdk_device_tool_get_serial
function.description:
Gets the serial number of this tool.
This value can be used to identify a physical tool (eg. a tablet pen) across program executions.
function.return: The serial ID for this tool

function.name: gdk_device_tool_get_tool_type
function.description: Gets the `GdkDeviceToolType` of the tool.
function.return: The physical type for this tool. This can be used to figure out what sort of pen is being used, such as an airbrush or a pencil.

function.name: gdk_display_beep
function.description: Emits a short beep on @display

function.name: gdk_display_close
function.description:
Closes the connection to the windowing system for the given display.
This cleans up associated resources.

function.name: gdk_display_create_gl_context
function.description:
Creates a new `GdkGLContext` for the `GdkDisplay`.
The context is disconnected from any particular surface or surface and cannot be used to draw to any surface. It can only be used to draw to non-surface framebuffers like textures.
If the creation of the `GdkGLContext` failed, @error will be set. Before using the returned `GdkGLContext`, you will need to call [method@Gdk.GLContext.make_current] or [method@Gdk.GLContext.realize].
Since: 4.6

function.name: gdk_display_device_is_grabbed
function.description: Returns %TRUE if there is an ongoing grab on @device for @display.
function.return: %TRUE if there is a grab in effect for @device.

function.name: gdk_display_flush
function.description:
Flushes any requests queued for the windowing system.
This happens automatically when the main loop blocks waiting for new events, but if your application is drawing without returning control to the main loop, you may need to call this function explicitly. A common case where this function needs to be called is when an application is executing drawing commands from a thread other than the thread where the main loop is running.
This is most useful for X11. On windowing systems where requests are handled synchronously, this function will do nothing.

function.name: gdk_display_get_app_launch_context
function.description: Returns a `GdkAppLaunchContext` suitable for launching applications on the given display.

function.name: gdk_display_get_clipboard
function.description: Gets the clipboard used for copy/paste operations.

function.name: gdk_display_get_default
function.description:
Gets the default `GdkDisplay`.
This is a convenience function for:
gdk_display_manager_get_default_display (gdk_display_manager_get ())
function.return: a `GdkDisplay`, or %NULL if there is no default display

function.name: gdk_display_get_default_seat
function.description:
Returns the default `GdkSeat` for this display.
Note that a display may not have a seat. In this case, this function will return %NULL.

function.name: gdk_display_get_dmabuf_formats
function.description:
Returns the dma-buf formats that are supported on this display.
GTK may use OpenGL or Vulkan to support some formats. Calling this function will then initialize them if they aren't yet.
The formats returned by this function can be used for negotiating buffer formats with producers such as v4l, pipewire or GStreamer.
To learn more about dma-bufs, see [class@Gdk.DmabufTextureBuilder].
Since: 4.14

function.name: gdk_display_get_monitor_at_surface
function.description: Gets the monitor in which the largest area of @surface resides.
function.return: the monitor with the largest overlap with @surface

function.name: gdk_display_get_monitors
function.description:
Gets the list of monitors associated with this display.
Subsequent calls to this function will always return the same list for the same display.
You can listen to the GListModel::items-changed signal on this list to monitor changes to the monitor of this display.

function.name: gdk_display_get_name
function.description: Gets the name of the display.
function.return: a string representing the display name. This string is owned by GDK and should not be modified or freed.

function.name: gdk_display_get_primary_clipboard
function.description:
Gets the clipboard used for the primary selection.
On backends where the primary clipboard is not supported natively, GDK emulates this clipboard locally.

function.name: gdk_display_get_setting
function.description: Retrieves a desktop-wide setting such as double-click time for the @display.

parameter.name: value
parameter.parameter_description: location to store the value of the setting

function.return: %TRUE if the setting existed and a value was stored in @value, %FALSE otherwise

function.name: gdk_display_get_startup_notification_id
function.description:
Gets the startup notification ID for a Wayland display, or %NULL if no ID has been defined.
Deprecated: 4.10

function.name: gdk_display_is_closed
function.description: Finds out if the display has been closed.

function.name: gdk_display_is_composited
function.description:
Returns whether surfaces can reasonably be expected to have their alpha channel drawn correctly on the screen.
Check [method@Gdk.Display.is_rgba] for whether the display supports an alpha channel.
On X11 this function returns whether a compositing manager is compositing on @display.
On modern displays, this value is always %TRUE.
function.return: Whether surfaces with RGBA visuals can reasonably be expected to have their alpha channels drawn correctly on the screen.

function.name: gdk_display_is_rgba
function.description:
Returns whether surfaces on this @display are created with an alpha channel.
Even if a %TRUE is returned, it is possible that the surface’s alpha channel won’t be honored when displaying the surface on the screen: in particular, for X an appropriate windowing manager and compositing manager must be running to provide appropriate display. Use [method@Gdk.Display.is_composited] to check if that is the case.
On modern displays, this value is always %TRUE.
function.return: %TRUE if surfaces are created with an alpha channel or %FALSE if the display does not support this functionality.

function.name: gdk_display_list_seats
function.description: Returns the list of seats known to @display.
function.return: the list of seats known to the `GdkDisplay`

function.name: gdk_display_manager_get
function.description:
Gets the singleton `GdkDisplayManager` object.
When called for the first time, this function consults the `GDK_BACKEND` environment variable to find out which of the supported GDK backends to use (in case GDK has been compiled with multiple backends).
Applications can use [func@set_allowed_backends] to limit what backends will be used.

function.name: gdk_display_manager_get_default_display
function.description: Gets the default `GdkDisplay`.

function.name: gdk_display_manager_list_displays
function.description: List all currently open displays.

function.name: gdk_display_manager_open_display
function.description: Opens a display.

parameter.name: name
parameter.parameter_description: the name of the display to open

function.return: a `GdkDisplay`, or %NULL if the display could not be opened

function.name: gdk_display_manager_set_default_display
function.description: Sets @display as the default display.

function.name: gdk_display_map_keycode
function.description:
Returns the keyvals bound to @keycode.
The Nth `GdkKeymapKey` in @keys is bound to the Nth keyval in @keyvals.
When a keycode is pressed by the user, the keyval from this list of entries is selected by considering the effective keyboard group and level.
Free the returned arrays with g_free().

parameter.name: keyvals
parameter.parameter_description: return location for array of keyvals

function.name: gdk_display_map_keyval
function.description:
Obtains a list of keycode/group/level combinations that will generate @keyval.
Groups and levels are two kinds of keyboard mode; in general, the level determines whether the top or bottom symbol on a key is used, and the group determines whether the left or right symbol is used.
On US keyboards, the shift key changes the keyboard level, and there are no groups. A group switch key might convert a keyboard between Hebrew to English modes, for example.
`GdkEventKey` contains a %group field that indicates the active keyboard group. The level is computed from the modifier mask.
The returned array should be freed with g_free().

parameter.name: keys
parameter.parameter_description: return location for an array of `GdkKeymapKey`

parameter.name: n_keys
parameter.parameter_description: return location for number of elements in returned array

function.return: %TRUE if keys were found and returned

function.name: gdk_display_notify_startup_complete
function.description:
Indicates to the GUI environment that the application has finished loading, using a given identifier.
GTK will call this function automatically for [GtkWindow](../gtk4/class.Window.html) with custom startup-notification identifier unless [gtk_window_set_auto_startup_notification()](../gtk4/method.Window.set_auto_startup_notification.html) is called to disable that feature.
Deprecated: 4.10: Using [method@Gdk.Toplevel.set_startup_id] is sufficient

parameter.name: startup_id
parameter.parameter_description: a startup-notification identifier, for which notification process should be completed

function.name: gdk_display_open
function.description:
Opens a display.
If opening the display fails, `NULL` is returned.

parameter.name: display_name
parameter.parameter_description: the name of the display to open

function.name: gdk_display_prepare_gl
function.description:
Checks that OpenGL is available for @self and ensures that it is properly initialized. When this fails, an @error will be set describing the error and this function returns %FALSE.
Note that even if this function succeeds, creating a `GdkGLContext` may still fail.
This function is idempotent. Calling it multiple times will just return the same value or error.
You never need to call this function, GDK will call it automatically as needed. But you can use it as a check when setting up code that might make use of OpenGL.
Since: 4.4

function.name: gdk_display_put_event
function.description:
Adds the given event to the event queue for @display.
Deprecated: 4.10: This function is only useful in very special situations and should not be used by applications.

function.name: gdk_display_supports_input_shapes
function.description:
Returns %TRUE if the display supports input shapes.
This means that [method@Gdk.Surface.set_input_region] can be used to modify the input shape of surfaces on @display.
On modern displays, this value is always %TRUE.
function.return: %TRUE if surfaces with modified input shape are supported

function.name: gdk_display_supports_shadow_width
function.description:
Returns whether it's possible for a surface to draw outside of the window area.
If %TRUE is returned the application decides if it wants to draw shadows. If %FALSE is returned, the compositor decides if it wants to draw shadows.
Since: 4.14
function.return: %TRUE if surfaces can draw shadows or %FALSE if the display does not support this functionality.

function.name: gdk_display_sync
function.description:
Flushes any requests queued for the windowing system and waits until all requests have been handled.
This is often used for making sure that the display is synchronized with the current state of the program. Calling [method@Gdk.Display.sync] before [method@GdkX11.Display.error_trap_pop] makes sure that any errors generated from earlier requests are handled before the error trap is removed.
This is most useful for X11. On windowing systems where requests are handled synchronously, this function will do nothing.

function.name: gdk_display_translate_key
function.description:
Translates the contents of a `GdkEventKey` into a keyval, effective group, and level.
Modifiers that affected the translation and are thus unavailable for application use are returned in @consumed_modifiers.
The @effective_group is the group that was actually used for the translation; some keys such as Enter are not affected by the active keyboard group. The @level is derived from @state.
@consumed_modifiers gives modifiers that should be masked out from @state when comparing this key press to a keyboard shortcut. For instance, on a US keyboard, the `plus` symbol is shifted, so when comparing a key press to a `<Control>plus` accelerator `<Shift>` should be masked out.
This function should rarely be needed, since `GdkEventKey` already contains the translated keyval. It is exported for the benefit of virtualized test environments.

parameter.name: consumed
parameter.parameter_description: return location for modifiers that were used to determine the group or level

function.return: %TRUE if there was a keyval bound to keycode/state/group.

function.name: gdk_dmabuf_error_quark
function.description: Registers an error quark for [class@Gdk.DmabufTexture] errors.

function.name: gdk_dmabuf_formats_contains
function.description:
Returns whether a given format is contained in @formats.
Since: 4.14
function.return: `TRUE` if the format specified by the arguments is part of @formats

function.name: gdk_dmabuf_formats_equal
function.description:
Returns whether @formats1 and @formats2 contain the same dmabuf formats, in the same order.
Since: 4.14

function.name: gdk_dmabuf_formats_get_format
function.description:
Gets the fourcc code and modifier for a format that is contained in @formats.
Since: 4.14

parameter.name: idx
parameter.parameter_description: the index of the format to return

parameter.name: fourcc
parameter.parameter_description: return location for the format code

parameter.name: modifier
parameter.parameter_description: return location for the format modifier

function.name: gdk_dmabuf_formats_get_n_formats
function.description:
Returns the number of formats that the @formats object contains.
Note that DMA buffers are a Linux concept, so on other platforms, [method@Gdk.DmabufFormats.get_n_formats] will always return zero.
Since: 4.14

function.name: gdk_dmabuf_formats_ref
function.description:
Increases the reference count of @formats.
Since: 4.14

function.name: gdk_dmabuf_formats_unref
function.description:
Decreases the reference count of @formats.
When the reference count reaches zero, the object is freed.
Since: 4.14

function.name: gdk_dmabuf_texture_builder_build
function.description:
Builds a new `GdkTexture` with the values set up in the builder.
It is a programming error to call this function if any mandatory property has not been set.
Not all formats defined in the `drm_fourcc.h` header are supported. You can use [method@Gdk.Display.get_dmabuf_formats] to get a list of supported formats. If the format is not supported by GTK, %NULL will be returned and @error will be set.
The `destroy` function gets called when the returned texture gets released.
It is the responsibility of the caller to keep the file descriptors for the planes open until the created texture is no longer used, and close them afterwards (possibly using the @destroy notify).
It is possible to call this function multiple times to create multiple textures, possibly with changing properties in between.
Since: 4.14

parameter.name: destroy
parameter.parameter_description: destroy function to be called when the texture is released

parameter.name: data
parameter.parameter_description: user data to pass to the destroy function

function.return: a newly built `GdkTexture` or `NULL` if the format is not supported

function.name: gdk_dmabuf_texture_builder_get_color_state
function.description:
Gets the color state previously set via gdk_dmabuf_texture_builder_set_color_state().
Since: 4.16

function.name: gdk_dmabuf_texture_builder_get_display
function.description:
Returns the display that this texture builder is associated with.
Since: 4.14

function.name: gdk_dmabuf_texture_builder_get_fd
function.description:
Gets the file descriptor for a plane.
Since: 4.14

parameter.name: plane
parameter.parameter_description: the plane to get the fd for

function.name: gdk_dmabuf_texture_builder_get_fourcc
function.description:
Gets the format previously set via gdk_dmabuf_texture_builder_set_fourcc() or 0 if the format wasn't set.
The format is specified as a fourcc code.
Since: 4.14

function.name: gdk_dmabuf_texture_builder_get_height
function.description:
Gets the height previously set via gdk_dmabuf_texture_builder_set_height() or 0 if the height wasn't set.
Since: 4.14

function.name: gdk_dmabuf_texture_builder_get_modifier
function.description:
Gets the modifier value.
Since: 4.14

function.name: gdk_dmabuf_texture_builder_get_n_planes
function.description:
Gets the number of planes.
Since: 4.14

function.name: gdk_dmabuf_texture_builder_get_offset
function.description:
Gets the offset value for a plane.
Since: 4.14

parameter.name: plane
parameter.parameter_description: the plane to get the offset for

function.name: gdk_dmabuf_texture_builder_get_premultiplied
function.description:
Whether the data is premultiplied.
Since: 4.14

function.name: gdk_dmabuf_texture_builder_get_stride
function.description:
Gets the stride value for a plane.
Since: 4.14

parameter.name: plane
parameter.parameter_description: the plane to get the stride for

function.name: gdk_dmabuf_texture_builder_get_update_region
function.description:
Gets the region previously set via gdk_dmabuf_texture_builder_set_update_region() or %NULL if none was set.
Since: 4.14

function.name: gdk_dmabuf_texture_builder_get_update_texture
function.description:
Gets the texture previously set via gdk_dmabuf_texture_builder_set_update_texture() or %NULL if none was set.
Since: 4.14

function.name: gdk_dmabuf_texture_builder_get_width
function.description:
Gets the width previously set via gdk_dmabuf_texture_builder_set_width() or 0 if the width wasn't set.
Since: 4.14

function.name: gdk_dmabuf_texture_builder_set_color_state
function.description:
Sets the color state for the texture.
By default, the colorstate is `NULL`. In that case, GTK will choose the correct colorstate based on the format. If you don't know what colorstates are, this is probably the right thing.
Since: 4.16

parameter.name: color_state
parameter.parameter_description: a `GdkColorState` or `NULL` to unset the colorstate.

function.name: gdk_dmabuf_texture_builder_set_display
function.description:
Sets the display that this texture builder is associated with.
The display is used to determine the supported dma-buf formats.
Since: 4.14

function.name: gdk_dmabuf_texture_builder_set_fd
function.description:
Sets the file descriptor for a plane.
Since: 4.14

parameter.name: plane
parameter.parameter_description: the plane to set the fd for

function.name: gdk_dmabuf_texture_builder_set_fourcc
function.description:
Sets the format of the texture.
The format is specified as a fourcc code.
The format must be set before calling [method@Gdk.GLTextureBuilder.build].
Since: 4.14

parameter.name: fourcc
parameter.parameter_description: the texture's format or 0 to unset

function.name: gdk_dmabuf_texture_builder_set_height
function.description:
Sets the height of the texture.
The height must be set before calling [method@Gdk.GLTextureBuilder.build].
Since: 4.14

parameter.name: height
parameter.parameter_description: the texture's height or 0 to unset

function.name: gdk_dmabuf_texture_builder_set_modifier
function.description:
Sets the modifier.
Since: 4.14

function.name: gdk_dmabuf_texture_builder_set_n_planes
function.description:
Sets the number of planes of the texture.
Since: 4.14

function.name: gdk_dmabuf_texture_builder_set_offset
function.description:
Sets the offset for a plane.
Since: 4.14

parameter.name: plane
parameter.parameter_description: the plane to set the offset for

function.name: gdk_dmabuf_texture_builder_set_premultiplied
function.description:
Sets whether the data is premultiplied.
Unless otherwise specified, all formats including alpha channels are assumed to be premultiplied.
Since: 4.14

function.name: gdk_dmabuf_texture_builder_set_stride
function.description:
Sets the stride for a plane.
The stride must be set for all planes before calling [method@Gdk.GLTextureBuilder.build].
Since: 4.14

parameter.name: plane
parameter.parameter_description: the plane to set the stride for

function.name: gdk_dmabuf_texture_builder_set_update_region
function.description:
Sets the region to be updated by this texture. Together with [property@Gdk.DmabufTextureBuilder:update-texture] this describes an update of a previous texture.
When rendering animations of large textures, it is possible that consecutive textures are only updating contents in parts of the texture. It is then possible to describe this update via these two properties, so that GTK can avoid rerendering parts that did not change.
An example would be a screen recording where only the mouse pointer moves.
Since: 4.14

function.name: gdk_dmabuf_texture_builder_set_update_texture
function.description:
Sets the texture to be updated by this texture. See [method@Gdk.DmabufTextureBuilder.set_update_region] for an explanation.
Since: 4.14

function.name: gdk_dmabuf_texture_builder_set_width
function.description:
Sets the width of the texture.
The width must be set before calling [method@Gdk.GLTextureBuilder.build].
Since: 4.14

parameter.name: width
parameter.parameter_description: The texture's width or 0 to unset

function.name: gdk_dnd_event_get_drop
function.description: Gets the `GdkDrop` object from a DND event.

function.name: gdk_drag_action_is_unique
function.description:
Checks if @action represents a single action or includes multiple actions.
When @action is 0 - ie no action was given, %TRUE is returned.
function.return: %TRUE if exactly one action was given

function.name: gdk_drag_begin
function.description:
Starts a drag and creates a new drag context for it.
This function is called by the drag source. After this call, you probably want to set up the drag icon using the surface returned by [method@Gdk.Drag.get_drag_surface].
This function returns a reference to the [class@Gdk.Drag] object, but GTK keeps its own reference as well, as long as the DND operation is going on.
Note: if @actions include %GDK_ACTION_MOVE, you need to listen for the [signal@Gdk.Drag::dnd-finished] signal and delete the data at the source if [method@Gdk.Drag.get_selected_action] returns %GDK_ACTION_MOVE.

parameter.name: surface
parameter.parameter_description: the source surface for this drag

parameter.name: device
parameter.parameter_description: the device that controls this drag

parameter.name: actions
parameter.parameter_description: the actions supported by this drag

parameter.name: dx
parameter.parameter_description: the x offset to @device's position where the drag nominally started

parameter.name: dy
parameter.parameter_description: the y offset to @device's position where the drag nominally started

function.name: gdk_drag_drop_done
function.description:
Informs GDK that the drop ended.
Passing %FALSE for @success may trigger a drag cancellation animation.
This function is called by the drag source, and should be the last call before dropping the reference to the @drag.
The `GdkDrag` will only take the first [method@Gdk.Drag.drop_done] call as effective, if this function is called multiple times, all subsequent calls will be ignored.

parameter.name: success
parameter.parameter_description: whether the drag was ultimatively successful

function.name: gdk_drag_get_actions
function.description: Determines the bitmask of possible actions proposed by the source.

function.name: gdk_drag_get_content
function.description: Returns the `GdkContentProvider` associated to the `GdkDrag` object.

function.name: gdk_drag_get_device
function.description: Returns the `GdkDevice` associated to the `GdkDrag` object.

function.name: gdk_drag_get_display
function.description: Gets the `GdkDisplay` that the drag object was created for.

function.name: gdk_drag_get_drag_surface
function.description:
Returns the surface on which the drag icon should be rendered during the drag operation.
Note that the surface may not be available until the drag operation has begun. GDK will move the surface in accordance with the ongoing drag operation. The surface is owned by @drag and will be destroyed when the drag operation is over.

function.name: gdk_drag_get_formats
function.description: Retrieves the formats supported by this `GdkDrag` object.

function.name: gdk_drag_get_selected_action
function.description: Determines the action chosen by the drag destination.

function.name: gdk_drag_get_surface
function.description: Returns the `GdkSurface` where the drag originates.

function.name: gdk_drag_set_hotspot
function.description:
Sets the position of the drag surface that will be kept under the cursor hotspot.
Initially, the hotspot is at the top left corner of the drag surface.

parameter.name: hot_x
parameter.parameter_description: x coordinate of the drag surface hotspot

parameter.name: hot_y
parameter.parameter_description: y coordinate of the drag surface hotspot

function.name: gdk_drag_surface_present
function.description: Present @drag_surface.

parameter.name: width
parameter.parameter_description: the unconstrained drag_surface width to layout

parameter.name: height
parameter.parameter_description: the unconstrained drag_surface height to layout

function.return: %FALSE if it failed to be presented, otherwise %TRUE.

function.name: gdk_drag_surface_size_set_size
function.description:
Sets the size the drag surface prefers to be resized to.
Since: 4.12

function.name: gdk_draw_context_begin_frame
function.description:
Indicates that you are beginning the process of redrawing @region on the @context's surface.
Calling this function begins a drawing operation using @context on the surface that @context was created from. The actual requirements and guarantees for the drawing operation vary for different implementations of drawing, so a [class@Gdk.CairoContext] and a [class@Gdk.GLContext] need to be treated differently.
A call to this function is a requirement for drawing and must be followed by a call to [method@Gdk.DrawContext.end_frame], which will complete the drawing operation and ensure the contents become visible on screen.
Note that the @region passed to this function is the minimum region that needs to be drawn and depending on implementation, windowing system and hardware in use, it might be necessary to draw a larger region. Drawing implementation must use [method@Gdk.DrawContext.get_frame_region] to query the region that must be drawn.
When using GTK, the widget system automatically places calls to gdk_draw_context_begin_frame() and gdk_draw_context_end_frame() via the use of [GskRenderer](../gsk4/class.Renderer.html)s, so application code does not need to call these functions explicitly.
Deprecated: 4.16: Drawing directly to the surface is no longer recommended. Use `GskRenderNode` and `GskRenderer`.

parameter.name: context
parameter.parameter_description: the `GdkDrawContext` used to draw the frame. The context must have a surface.

parameter.name: region
parameter.parameter_description: minimum region that should be drawn

function.name: gdk_draw_context_end_frame
function.description:
Ends a drawing operation started with gdk_draw_context_begin_frame().
This makes the drawing available on screen. See [method@Gdk.DrawContext.begin_frame] for more details about drawing.
When using a [class@Gdk.GLContext], this function may call `glFlush()` implicitly before returning; it is not recommended to call `glFlush()` explicitly before calling this function.
Deprecated: 4.16: Drawing directly to the surface is no longer recommended. Use `GskRenderNode` and `GskRenderer`.

function.name: gdk_draw_context_get_display
function.description: Retrieves the `GdkDisplay` the @context is created for

function.name: gdk_draw_context_get_frame_region
function.description:
Retrieves the region that is currently being repainted.
After a call to [method@Gdk.DrawContext.begin_frame] this function will return a union of the region passed to that function and the area of the surface that the @context determined needs to be repainted.
If @context is not in between calls to [method@Gdk.DrawContext.begin_frame] and [method@Gdk.DrawContext.end_frame], %NULL will be returned.
Deprecated: 4.16: Drawing directly to the surface is no longer recommended. Use `GskRenderNode` and `GskRenderer`.

function.name: gdk_draw_context_get_surface
function.description: Retrieves the surface that @context is bound to.

function.name: gdk_draw_context_is_in_frame
function.description:
Returns %TRUE if @context is in the process of drawing to its surface.
This is the case between calls to [method@Gdk.DrawContext.begin_frame] and [method@Gdk.DrawContext.end_frame]. In this situation, drawing commands may be effecting the contents of the @context's surface.
Deprecated: 4.16: Drawing directly to the surface is no longer recommended. Use `GskRenderNode` and `GskRenderer`.
function.return: %TRUE if the context is between [method@Gdk.DrawContext.begin_frame] and [method@Gdk.DrawContext.end_frame] calls.

function.name: gdk_drop_finish
function.description:
Ends the drag operation after a drop.
The @action must be a single action selected from the actions available via [method@Gdk.Drop.get_actions].

parameter.name: action
parameter.parameter_description: the action performed by the destination or 0 if the drop failed

function.name: gdk_drop_get_actions
function.description:
Returns the possible actions for this `GdkDrop`.
If this value contains multiple actions - i.e. [func@Gdk.DragAction.is_unique] returns %FALSE for the result - [method@Gdk.Drop.finish] must choose the action to use when accepting the drop. This will only happen if you passed %GDK_ACTION_ASK as one of the possible actions in [method@Gdk.Drop.status]. %GDK_ACTION_ASK itself will not be included in the actions returned by this function.
This value may change over the lifetime of the [class@Gdk.Drop] both as a response to source side actions as well as to calls to [method@Gdk.Drop.status] or [method@Gdk.Drop.finish]. The source side will not change this value anymore once a drop has started.

function.name: gdk_drop_get_device
function.description: Returns the `GdkDevice` performing the drop.

function.name: gdk_drop_get_display
function.description: Gets the `GdkDisplay` that @self was created for.

function.name: gdk_drop_get_drag
function.description:
If this is an in-app drag-and-drop operation, returns the `GdkDrag` that corresponds to this drop.
If it is not, %NULL is returned.

function.name: gdk_drop_get_formats
function.description: Returns the `GdkContentFormats` that the drop offers the data to be read in.

function.name: gdk_drop_get_surface
function.description: Returns the `GdkSurface` performing the drop.

function.name: gdk_drop_read_async
function.description: Asynchronously read the dropped data from a `GdkDrop` in a format that complies with one of the mime types.

parameter.name: mime_types
parameter.parameter_description: pointer to an array of mime types

parameter.name: io_priority
parameter.parameter_description: the I/O priority for the read operation

parameter.name: callback
parameter.parameter_description: a `GAsyncReadyCallback` to call when the request is satisfied

function.name: gdk_drop_read_finish
function.description:
Finishes an async drop read operation.
Note that you must not use blocking read calls on the returned stream in the GTK thread, since some platforms might require communication with GTK to complete the data transfer. You can use async APIs such as g_input_stream_read_bytes_async().
See [method@Gdk.Drop.read_async].

parameter.name: out_mime_type
parameter.parameter_description: return location for the used mime type

parameter.name: error
parameter.parameter_description: location to store error information on failure

function.name: gdk_drop_read_value_async
function.description:
Asynchronously request the drag operation's contents converted to the given @type.
For local drag-and-drop operations that are available in the given `GType`, the value will be copied directly. Otherwise, GDK will try to use [func@Gdk.content_deserialize_async] to convert the data.

parameter.name: io_priority
parameter.parameter_description: the I/O priority of the request.

parameter.name: callback
parameter.parameter_description: callback to call when the request is satisfied

parameter.name: user_data
parameter.parameter_description: the data to pass to callback function

function.name: gdk_drop_read_value_finish
function.description:
Finishes an async drop read.
See [method@Gdk.Drop.read_value_async].

parameter.name: error
parameter.parameter_description: a `GError` location to store the error occurring

function.name: gdk_drop_status
function.description:
Selects all actions that are potentially supported by the destination.
When calling this function, do not restrict the passed in actions to the ones provided by [method@Gdk.Drop.get_actions]. Those actions may change in the future, even depending on the actions you provide here.
The @preferred action is a hint to the drag-and-drop mechanism about which action to use when multiple actions are possible.
This function should be called by drag destinations in response to %GDK_DRAG_ENTER or %GDK_DRAG_MOTION events. If the destination does not yet know the exact actions it supports, it should set any possible actions first and then later call this function again.

parameter.name: actions
parameter.parameter_description: Supported actions of the destination, or 0 to indicate that a drop will not be accepted

parameter.name: preferred
parameter.parameter_description: A unique action that's a member of @actions indicating the preferred action

function.name: gdk_event_get_axes
function.description:
Extracts all axis values from an event.
To find out which axes are used, use [method@Gdk.DeviceTool.get_axes] on the device tool returned by [method@Gdk.Event.get_device_tool].

parameter.name: axes
parameter.parameter_description: the array of values for all axes

function.name: gdk_event_get_axis
function.description:
Extract the axis value for a particular axis use from an event structure.
To find out which axes are used, use [method@Gdk.DeviceTool.get_axes] on the device tool returned by [method@Gdk.Event.get_device_tool].

parameter.name: axis_use
parameter.parameter_description: the axis use to look for

parameter.name: value
parameter.parameter_description: location to store the value found

function.return: %TRUE if the specified axis was found, otherwise %FALSE

function.name: gdk_event_get_device
function.description: Returns the device of an event.

function.name: gdk_event_get_device_tool
function.description:
Returns a `GdkDeviceTool` representing the tool that caused the event.
If the was not generated by a device that supports different tools (such as a tablet), this function will return %NULL.
Note: the `GdkDeviceTool` will be constant during the application lifetime, if settings must be stored persistently across runs, see [method@Gdk.DeviceTool.get_serial].

function.name: gdk_event_get_display
function.description: Retrieves the display associated to the @event.

function.name: gdk_event_get_event_sequence
function.description:
Returns the event sequence to which the event belongs.
Related touch events are connected in a sequence. Other events typically don't have event sequence information.
function.return: the event sequence that the event belongs to

function.name: gdk_event_get_event_type
function.description: Retrieves the type of the event.

function.name: gdk_event_get_history
function.description:
Retrieves the history of the device that @event is for, as a list of time and coordinates.
The history includes positions that are not delivered as separate events to the application because they occurred in the same frame as @event.
Note that only motion and scroll events record history, and motion events do it only if one of the mouse buttons is down, or the device has a tool.

parameter.name: out_n_coords
parameter.parameter_description: Return location for the length of the returned array

function.return: an array of time and coordinates

function.name: gdk_event_get_modifier_state
function.description: Returns the modifier state field of an event.

function.name: gdk_event_get_pointer_emulated
function.description:
Returns whether this event is an 'emulated' pointer event.
Emulated pointer events typically originate from a touch events.

function.name: gdk_event_get_position
function.description:
Extract the event surface relative x/y coordinates from an event.
This position is in [surface coordinates](coordinates.html).

parameter.name: x
parameter.parameter_description: location to put event surface x coordinate

parameter.name: y
parameter.parameter_description: location to put event surface y coordinate

function.name: gdk_event_get_seat
function.description: Returns the seat that originated the event.

function.name: gdk_event_get_surface
function.description: Extracts the surface associated with an event.

function.name: gdk_event_get_time
function.description:
Returns the timestamp of @event.
Not all events have timestamps. In that case, this function returns %GDK_CURRENT_TIME.

function.name: gdk_event_ref
function.description: Increase the ref count of @event.

function.name: gdk_event_triggers_context_menu
function.description:
Returns whether a `GdkEvent` should trigger a context menu, according to platform conventions.
The right mouse button typically triggers context menus. On macOS, Control+left mouse button also triggers.
This function should always be used instead of simply checking for
```c event->button == GDK_BUTTON_SECONDARY ```

parameter.name: event
parameter.parameter_description: a `GdkEvent`, currently only button events are meaningful values

function.return: %TRUE if the event should trigger a context menu.

function.name: gdk_event_unref
function.description:
Decrease the ref count of @event.
If the last reference is dropped, the structure is freed.

function.name: gdk_events_get_angle
function.description:
Returns the relative angle from @event1 to @event2.
The relative angle is the angle between the X axis and the line through both events' positions. The rotation direction for positive angles is from the positive X axis towards the positive Y axis.
This assumes that both events have X/Y information. If not, this function returns %FALSE.

parameter.name: angle
parameter.parameter_description: return location for the relative angle between both events

function.return: %TRUE if the angle could be calculated.

function.name: gdk_events_get_center
function.description:
Returns the point halfway between the events' positions.
This assumes that both events have X/Y information. If not, this function returns %FALSE.

parameter.name: x
parameter.parameter_description: return location for the X coordinate of the center

parameter.name: y
parameter.parameter_description: return location for the Y coordinate of the center

function.return: %TRUE if the center could be calculated.

function.name: gdk_events_get_distance
function.description:
Returns the distance between the event locations.
This assumes that both events have X/Y information. If not, this function returns %FALSE.
function.return: %TRUE if the distance could be calculated.

function.name: gdk_file_list_get_files
function.description:
Retrieves the list of files inside a `GdkFileList`.
This function is meant for language bindings.
Since: 4.6

function.name: gdk_file_list_new_from_array
function.description:
Creates a new `GdkFileList` for the given array of files.
This function is meant to be used by language bindings.
Since: 4.8

parameter.name: files
parameter.parameter_description: the files to add to the list

parameter.name: n_files
parameter.parameter_description: the number of files in the array

function.name: gdk_file_list_new_from_list
function.description:
Creates a new files list container from a singly linked list of `GFile` instances.
This function is meant to be used by language bindings
Since: 4.8

function.name: gdk_focus_event_get_in
function.description: Extracts whether this event is about focus entering or leaving the surface.

function.name: gdk_frame_clock_begin_updating
function.description:
Starts updates for an animation.
Until a matching call to [method@Gdk.FrameClock.end_updating] is made, the frame clock will continually request a new frame with the %GDK_FRAME_CLOCK_PHASE_UPDATE phase. This function may be called multiple times and frames will be requested until gdk_frame_clock_end_updating() is called the same number of times.

function.name: gdk_frame_clock_end_updating
function.description:
Stops updates for an animation.
See the documentation for [method@Gdk.FrameClock.begin_updating].

function.name: gdk_frame_clock_get_current_timings
function.description: Gets the frame timings for the current frame.
function.return: the `GdkFrameTimings` for the frame currently being processed, or even no frame is being processed, for the previous frame. Before any frames have been processed, returns %NULL.

function.name: gdk_frame_clock_get_fps
function.description: Calculates the current frames-per-second, based on the frame timings of @frame_clock.

function.name: gdk_frame_clock_get_frame_counter
function.description: `GdkFrameClock` maintains a 64-bit counter that increments for each frame drawn.
function.return: inside frame processing, the value of the frame counter for the current frame. Outside of frame processing, the frame counter for the last frame.

function.name: gdk_frame_clock_get_frame_time
function.description:
Gets the time that should currently be used for animations.
Inside the processing of a frame, it’s the time used to compute the animation position of everything in a frame. Outside of a frame, it's the time of the conceptual “previous frame,” which may be either the actual previous frame time, or if that’s too old, an updated time.
function.return: a timestamp in microseconds, in the timescale of of g_get_monotonic_time().

function.name: gdk_frame_clock_get_history_start
function.description:
Returns the frame counter for the oldest frame available in history.
`GdkFrameClock` internally keeps a history of `GdkFrameTimings` objects for recent frames that can be retrieved with [method@Gdk.FrameClock.get_timings]. The set of stored frames is the set from the counter values given by [method@Gdk.FrameClock.get_history_start] and [method@Gdk.FrameClock.get_frame_counter], inclusive.
function.return: the frame counter value for the oldest frame that is available in the internal frame history of the `GdkFrameClock`

function.name: gdk_frame_clock_get_refresh_info
function.description:
Predicts a presentation time, based on history.
Using the frame history stored in the frame clock, finds the last known presentation time and refresh interval, and assuming that presentation times are separated by the refresh interval, predicts a presentation time that is a multiple of the refresh interval after the last presentation time, and later than @base_time.

parameter.name: base_time
parameter.parameter_description: base time for determining a presentaton time

parameter.name: refresh_interval_return
parameter.parameter_description: a location to store the determined refresh interval, or %NULL. A default refresh interval of 1/60th of a second will be stored if no history is present.

parameter.name: presentation_time_return
parameter.parameter_description: a location to store the next candidate presentation time after the given base time. 0 will be will be stored if no history is present.

function.name: gdk_frame_clock_get_timings
function.description:
Retrieves a `GdkFrameTimings` object holding timing information for the current frame or a recent frame.
The `GdkFrameTimings` object may not yet be complete: see [method@Gdk.FrameTimings.get_complete] and [method@Gdk.FrameClock.get_history_start].

parameter.name: frame_counter
parameter.parameter_description: the frame counter value identifying the frame to be received

function.return: the `GdkFrameTimings` object for the specified frame, or %NULL if it is not available

function.name: gdk_frame_clock_request_phase
function.description:
Asks the frame clock to run a particular phase.
The signal corresponding the requested phase will be emitted the next time the frame clock processes. Multiple calls to gdk_frame_clock_request_phase() will be combined together and only one frame processed. If you are displaying animated content and want to continually request the %GDK_FRAME_CLOCK_PHASE_UPDATE phase for a period of time, you should use [method@Gdk.FrameClock.begin_updating] instead, since this allows GTK to adjust system parameters to get maximally smooth animations.

function.name: gdk_frame_timings_get_complete
function.description:
Returns whether @timings are complete.
The timing information in a `GdkFrameTimings` is filled in incrementally as the frame as drawn and passed off to the window system for processing and display to the user. The accessor functions for `GdkFrameTimings` can return 0 to indicate an unavailable value for two reasons: either because the information is not yet available, or because it isn't available at all.
Once this function returns %TRUE for a frame, you can be certain that no further values will become available and be stored in the `GdkFrameTimings`.
function.return: %TRUE if all information that will be available for the frame has been filled in.

function.name: gdk_frame_timings_get_frame_counter
function.description: Gets the frame counter value of the `GdkFrameClock` when this frame was drawn.
function.return: the frame counter value for this frame

function.name: gdk_frame_timings_get_frame_time
function.description:
Returns the frame time for the frame.
This is the time value that is typically used to time animations for the frame. See [method@Gdk.FrameClock.get_frame_time].
function.return: the frame time for the frame, in the timescale of g_get_monotonic_time()

function.name: gdk_frame_timings_get_predicted_presentation_time
function.description:
Gets the predicted time at which this frame will be displayed.
Although no predicted time may be available, if one is available, it will be available while the frame is being generated, in contrast to [method@Gdk.FrameTimings.get_presentation_time], which is only available after the frame has been presented.
In general, if you are simply animating, you should use [method@Gdk.FrameClock.get_frame_time] rather than this function, but this function is useful for applications that want exact control over latency. For example, a movie player may want this information for Audio/Video synchronization.
function.return: The predicted time at which the frame will be presented, in the timescale of g_get_monotonic_time(), or 0 if no predicted presentation time is available.

function.name: gdk_frame_timings_get_presentation_time
function.description:
Reurns the presentation time.
This is the time at which the frame became visible to the user.
function.return: the time the frame was displayed to the user, in the timescale of g_get_monotonic_time(), or 0 if no presentation time is available. See [method@Gdk.FrameTimings.get_complete]

function.name: gdk_frame_timings_get_refresh_interval
function.description:
Gets the natural interval between presentation times for the display that this frame was displayed on.
Frame presentation usually happens during the “vertical blanking interval”.
function.return: the refresh interval of the display, in microseconds, or 0 if the refresh interval is not available. See [method@Gdk.FrameTimings.get_complete].

function.name: gdk_frame_timings_ref
function.description: Increases the reference count of @timings.

function.name: gdk_frame_timings_unref
function.description:
Decreases the reference count of @timings.
If @timings is no longer referenced, it will be freed.

function.name: gdk_gl_context_clear_current
function.description:
Clears the current `GdkGLContext`.
Any OpenGL call after this function returns will be ignored until [method@Gdk.GLContext.make_current] is called.

function.name: gdk_gl_context_get_allowed_apis
function.description:
Gets the allowed APIs set via gdk_gl_context_set_allowed_apis().
Since: 4.6

function.name: gdk_gl_context_get_api
function.description:
Gets the API currently in use.
If the renderer has not been realized yet, 0 is returned.
Since: 4.6

function.name: gdk_gl_context_get_current
function.description: Retrieves the current `GdkGLContext`.

function.name: gdk_gl_context_get_debug_enabled
function.description:
Retrieves whether the context is doing extra validations and runtime checking.
See [method@Gdk.GLContext.set_debug_enabled].

function.name: gdk_gl_context_get_display
function.description: Retrieves the display the @context is created for

function.name: gdk_gl_context_get_forward_compatible
function.description:
Retrieves whether the context is forward-compatible.
See [method@Gdk.GLContext.set_forward_compatible].
function.return: %TRUE if the context should be forward-compatible

function.name: gdk_gl_context_get_required_version
function.description:
Retrieves required OpenGL version set as a requirement for the @context realization. It will not change even if a greater OpenGL version is supported and used after the @context is realized. See [method@Gdk.GLContext.get_version] for the real version in use.
See [method@Gdk.GLContext.set_required_version].

parameter.name: major
parameter.parameter_description: return location for the major version to request

parameter.name: minor
parameter.parameter_description: return location for the minor version to request

function.name: gdk_gl_context_get_shared_context
function.description:
Used to retrieves the `GdkGLContext` that this @context share data with.
As many contexts can share data now and no single shared context exists anymore, this function has been deprecated and now always returns %NULL.
Deprecated: 4.4: Use [method@Gdk.GLContext.is_shared] to check if contexts can be shared.

function.name: gdk_gl_context_get_surface
function.description: Retrieves the surface used by the @context.

function.name: gdk_gl_context_get_use_es
function.description: Checks whether the @context is using an OpenGL or OpenGL ES profile.

function.name: gdk_gl_context_get_version
function.description:
Retrieves the OpenGL version of the @context.
The @context must be realized prior to calling this function.

parameter.name: major
parameter.parameter_description: return location for the major version

parameter.name: minor
parameter.parameter_description: return location for the minor version

function.name: gdk_gl_context_is_legacy
function.description:
Whether the `GdkGLContext` is in legacy mode or not.
The `GdkGLContext` must be realized before calling this function.
When realizing a GL context, GDK will try to use the OpenGL 3.2 core profile; this profile removes all the OpenGL API that was deprecated prior to the 3.2 version of the specification. If the realization is successful, this function will return %FALSE.
If the underlying OpenGL implementation does not support core profiles, GDK will fall back to a pre-3.2 compatibility profile, and this function will return %TRUE.
You can use the value returned by this function to decide which kind of OpenGL API to use, or whether to do extension discovery, or what kind of shader programs to load.
function.return: %TRUE if the GL context is in legacy mode

function.name: gdk_gl_context_is_shared
function.description:
Checks if the two GL contexts can share resources.
When they can, the texture IDs from @other can be used in @self. This is particularly useful when passing `GdkGLTexture` objects between different contexts.
Contexts created for the same display with the same properties will always be compatible, even if they are created for different surfaces. For other contexts it depends on the GL backend.
Both contexts must be realized for this check to succeed. If either one is not, this function will return %FALSE.
Since: 4.4

parameter.name: other
parameter.parameter_description: the `GdkGLContext` that should be compatible with @self

function.return: %TRUE if the two GL contexts are compatible.

function.name: gdk_gl_context_make_current
function.description: Makes the @context the current one.

function.name: gdk_gl_context_realize
function.description:
Realizes the given `GdkGLContext`.
It is safe to call this function on a realized `GdkGLContext`.

function.name: gdk_gl_context_set_allowed_apis
function.description:
Sets the allowed APIs. When gdk_gl_context_realize() is called, only the allowed APIs will be tried. If you set this to 0, realizing will always fail.
If you set it on a realized context, the property will not have any effect. It is only relevant during gdk_gl_context_realize().
By default, all APIs are allowed.
Since: 4.6

function.name: gdk_gl_context_set_debug_enabled
function.description:
Sets whether the `GdkGLContext` should perform extra validations and runtime checking.
This is useful during development, but has additional overhead.
The `GdkGLContext` must not be realized or made current prior to calling this function.

parameter.name: enabled
parameter.parameter_description: whether to enable debugging in the context

function.name: gdk_gl_context_set_forward_compatible
function.description:
Sets whether the `GdkGLContext` should be forward-compatible.
Forward-compatible contexts must not support OpenGL functionality that has been marked as deprecated in the requested version; non-forward compatible contexts, on the other hand, must support both deprecated and non deprecated functionality.
The `GdkGLContext` must not be realized or made current prior to calling this function.

parameter.name: compatible
parameter.parameter_description: whether the context should be forward-compatible

function.name: gdk_gl_context_set_required_version
function.description:
Sets the major and minor version of OpenGL to request.
Setting @major and @minor to zero will use the default values.
Setting @major and @minor lower than the minimum versions required by GTK will result in the context choosing the minimum version.
The @context must not be realized or made current prior to calling this function.

function.name: gdk_gl_context_set_use_es
function.description:
Requests that GDK create an OpenGL ES context instead of an OpenGL one.
Not all platforms support OpenGL ES.
The @context must not have been realized.
By default, GDK will attempt to automatically detect whether the underlying GL implementation is OpenGL or OpenGL ES once the @context is realized.
You should check the return value of [method@Gdk.GLContext.get_use_es] after calling [method@Gdk.GLContext.realize] to decide whether to use the OpenGL or OpenGL ES API, extensions, or shaders.

parameter.name: use_es
parameter.parameter_description: whether the context should use OpenGL ES instead of OpenGL, or -1 to allow auto-detection

function.name: gdk_gl_error_quark
function.description: Registers an error quark for [class@Gdk.GLContext] errors.

function.name: gdk_gl_texture_builder_build
function.description:
Builds a new `GdkTexture` with the values set up in the builder.
The `destroy` function gets called when the returned texture gets released; either when the texture is finalized or by an explicit call to [method@Gdk.GLTexture.release]. It should release all GL resources associated with the texture, such as the [property@Gdk.GLTextureBuilder:id] and the [property@Gdk.GLTextureBuilder:sync].
Note that it is a programming error to call this function if any mandatory property has not been set.
It is possible to call this function multiple times to create multiple textures, possibly with changing properties in between.
Since: 4.12

parameter.name: destroy
parameter.parameter_description: destroy function to be called when the texture is released

parameter.name: data
parameter.parameter_description: user data to pass to the destroy function

function.name: gdk_gl_texture_builder_get_color_state
function.description:
Gets the color state previously set via gdk_gl_texture_builder_set_color_state().
Since: 4.16

function.name: gdk_gl_texture_builder_get_context
function.description:
Gets the context previously set via gdk_gl_texture_builder_set_context() or %NULL if none was set.
Since: 4.12

function.name: gdk_gl_texture_builder_get_format
function.description:
Gets the format previously set via gdk_gl_texture_builder_set_format().
Since: 4.12

function.name: gdk_gl_texture_builder_get_has_mipmap
function.description:
Gets whether the texture has a mipmap.
Since: 4.12
function.return: Whether the texture has a mipmap

function.name: gdk_gl_texture_builder_get_height
function.description:
Gets the height previously set via gdk_gl_texture_builder_set_height() or 0 if the height wasn't set.
Since: 4.12

function.name: gdk_gl_texture_builder_get_id
function.description:
Gets the texture id previously set via gdk_gl_texture_builder_set_id() or 0 if the id wasn't set.
Since: 4.12

function.name: gdk_gl_texture_builder_get_sync
function.description:
Gets the `GLsync` previously set via gdk_gl_texture_builder_set_sync().
Since: 4.12

function.name: gdk_gl_texture_builder_get_update_region
function.description:
Gets the region previously set via gdk_gl_texture_builder_set_update_region() or %NULL if none was set.
Since: 4.12

function.name: gdk_gl_texture_builder_get_update_texture
function.description:
Gets the texture previously set via gdk_gl_texture_builder_set_update_texture() or %NULL if none was set.
Since: 4.12

function.name: gdk_gl_texture_builder_get_width
function.description:
Gets the width previously set via gdk_gl_texture_builder_set_width() or 0 if the width wasn't set.
Since: 4.12

function.name: gdk_gl_texture_builder_set_color_state
function.description:
Sets the color state for the texture.
By default, the sRGB colorstate is used. If you don't know what colorstates are, this is probably the right thing.
Since: 4.16

function.name: gdk_gl_texture_builder_set_context
function.description:
Sets the context to be used for the texture. This is the context that owns the texture.
The context must be set before calling [method@Gdk.GLTextureBuilder.build].
Since: 4.12

parameter.name: context
parameter.parameter_description: The context the texture belongs to or %NULL to unset

function.name: gdk_gl_texture_builder_set_format
function.description:
Sets the format of the texture. The default is `GDK_MEMORY_R8G8B8A8_PREMULTIPLIED`.
The format is the preferred format the texture data should be downloaded to. The format must be supported by the GL version of [property@Gdk.GLTextureBuilder:context].
GDK's texture download code assumes that the format corresponds to the storage parameters of the GL texture in an obvious way. For example, a format of `GDK_MEMORY_R16G16B16A16_PREMULTIPLIED` is expected to be stored as `GL_RGBA16` texture, and `GDK_MEMORY_G8A8` is expected to be stored as `GL_RG8` texture.
Setting the right format is particularly useful when using high bit depth textures to preserve the bit depth, to set the correct value for unpremultiplied textures and to make sure opaque textures are treated as such.
Non-RGBA textures need to have swizzling parameters set up properly to be usable in GSK's shaders.
Since: 4.12

function.name: gdk_gl_texture_builder_set_has_mipmap
function.description:
Sets whether the texture has a mipmap. This allows the renderer and other users of the generated texture to use a higher quality downscaling.
Typically, the `glGenerateMipmap` function is used to generate a mimap.
Since: 4.12

parameter.name: has_mipmap
parameter.parameter_description: Whether the texture has a mipmap

function.name: gdk_gl_texture_builder_set_height
function.description:
Sets the height of the texture.
The height must be set before calling [method@Gdk.GLTextureBuilder.build].
Since: 4.12

parameter.name: height
parameter.parameter_description: The texture's height or 0 to unset

function.name: gdk_gl_texture_builder_set_id
function.description:
Sets the texture id of the texture. The texture id must remain unmodified until the texture was finalized. See [method@Gdk.GLTextureBuilder.build] for a longer discussion.
The id must be set before calling [method@Gdk.GLTextureBuilder.build].
Since: 4.12

parameter.name: id
parameter.parameter_description: The texture id to be used for creating the texture

function.name: gdk_gl_texture_builder_set_sync
function.description:
Sets the GLSync object to use for the texture.
GTK will wait on this object before using the created `GdkTexture`.
The `destroy` function that is passed to [method@Gdk.GLTextureBuilder.build] is responsible for freeing the sync object when it is no longer needed. The texture builder does not destroy it and it is the callers responsibility to make sure it doesn't leak.
Since: 4.12

function.name: gdk_gl_texture_builder_set_update_region
function.description:
Sets the region to be updated by this texture. Together with [property@Gdk.GLTextureBuilder:update-texture] this describes an update of a previous texture.
When rendering animations of large textures, it is possible that consecutive textures are only updating contents in parts of the texture. It is then possible to describe this update via these two properties, so that GTK can avoid rerendering parts that did not change.
An example would be a screen recording where only the mouse pointer moves.
Since: 4.12

function.name: gdk_gl_texture_builder_set_update_texture
function.description:
Sets the texture to be updated by this texture. See [method@Gdk.GLTextureBuilder.set_update_region] for an explanation.
Since: 4.12

function.name: gdk_gl_texture_builder_set_width
function.description:
Sets the width of the texture.
The width must be set before calling [method@Gdk.GLTextureBuilder.build].
Since: 4.12

parameter.name: width
parameter.parameter_description: The texture's width or 0 to unset

function.name: gdk_gl_texture_new
function.description:
Creates a new texture for an existing GL texture.
Note that the GL texture must not be modified until @destroy is called, which will happen when the GdkTexture object is finalized, or due to an explicit call of [method@Gdk.GLTexture.release].
Deprecated: 4.12: [class@Gdk.GLTextureBuilder] supersedes this function and provides extended functionality for creating GL textures.

parameter.name: id
parameter.parameter_description: the ID of a texture that was created with @context

parameter.name: width
parameter.parameter_description: the nominal width of the texture

parameter.name: height
parameter.parameter_description: the nominal height of the texture

parameter.name: destroy
parameter.parameter_description: a destroy notify that will be called when the GL resources are released

function.name: gdk_gl_texture_release
function.description:
Releases the GL resources held by a `GdkGLTexture`.
The texture contents are still available via the [method@Gdk.Texture.download] function, after this function has been called.

function.name: gdk_grab_broken_event_get_grab_surface
function.description: Extracts the grab surface from a grab broken event.

function.name: gdk_grab_broken_event_get_implicit
function.description: Checks whether the grab broken event is for an implicit grab.
function.return: %TRUE if the an implicit grab was broken

function.name: gdk_intern_mime_type
function.description:
Canonicalizes the given mime type and interns the result.
If @string is not a valid mime type, %NULL is returned instead. See RFC 2048 for the syntax if mime types.

parameter.name: string
parameter.parameter_description: string of a potential mime type

function.return: An interned string for the canonicalized mime type or %NULL if the string wasn't a valid mime type

function.name: gdk_key_event_get_consumed_modifiers
function.description: Extracts the consumed modifiers from a key event.

function.name: gdk_key_event_get_keycode
function.description: Extracts the keycode from a key event.

function.name: gdk_key_event_get_keyval
function.description: Extracts the keyval from a key event.

function.name: gdk_key_event_get_layout
function.description: Extracts the layout from a key event.

function.name: gdk_key_event_get_level
function.description: Extracts the shift level from a key event.

function.name: gdk_key_event_get_match
function.description:
Gets a keyval and modifier combination that will match the event.
See [method@Gdk.KeyEvent.matches].

function.name: gdk_key_event_is_modifier
function.description: Extracts whether the key event is for a modifier key.
function.return: %TRUE if the @event is for a modifier key

function.name: gdk_key_event_matches
function.description:
Matches a key event against a keyval and modifiers.
