This is typically used to trigger keyboard shortcuts such as Ctrl-C.
Partial matches are possible where the combination matches if the currently active group is ignored.
Note that we ignore Caps Lock for matching.

function.name: gdk_keyval_convert_case
function.description:
Obtains the upper- and lower-case versions of the keyval @symbol.
Examples of keyvals are `GDK_KEY_a`, `GDK_KEY_Enter`, `GDK_KEY_F1`, etc.

parameter.name: lower
parameter.parameter_description: return location for lowercase version of @symbol

parameter.name: upper
parameter.parameter_description: return location for uppercase version of @symbol

function.name: gdk_keyval_from_name
function.description:
Converts a key name to a key value.
The names are the same as those in the `gdk/gdkkeysyms.h` header file but without the leading “GDK_KEY_”.
function.return: the corresponding key value, or %GDK_KEY_VoidSymbol if the key name is not a valid key

function.name: gdk_keyval_is_lower
function.description: Returns %TRUE if the given key value is in lower case.
function.return: %TRUE if @keyval is in lower case, or if @keyval is not subject to case conversion.

function.name: gdk_keyval_is_upper
function.description: Returns %TRUE if the given key value is in upper case.
function.return: %TRUE if @keyval is in upper case, or if @keyval is not subject to case conversion.

function.name: gdk_keyval_name
function.description:
Converts a key value into a symbolic name.
The names are the same as those in the `gdk/gdkkeysyms.h` header file but without the leading “GDK_KEY_”.
function.return: a string containing the name of the key

function.name: gdk_keyval_to_lower
function.description: Converts a key value to lower case, if applicable.
function.return: the lower case form of @keyval, or @keyval itself if it is already in lower case or it is not subject to case conversion.

function.name: gdk_keyval_to_unicode
function.description:
Convert from a GDK key symbol to the corresponding Unicode character.
Note that the conversion does not take the current locale into consideration, which might be expected for particular keyvals, such as %GDK_KEY_KP_Decimal.
function.return: the corresponding unicode character, or 0 if there is no corresponding character.

function.name: gdk_keyval_to_upper
function.description: Converts a key value to upper case, if applicable.
function.return: the upper case form of @keyval, or @keyval itself if it is already in upper case or it is not subject to case conversion.

function.name: gdk_memory_texture_builder_build
function.description:
Builds a new `GdkTexture` with the values set up in the builder.
Note that it is a programming error to call this function if any mandatory property has not been set.
It is possible to call this function multiple times to create multiple textures, possibly with changing properties in between.
Since: 4.16

function.name: gdk_memory_texture_builder_get_bytes
function.description:
Gets the bytes previously set via gdk_memory_texture_builder_set_bytes() or %NULL if none was set.
Since: 4.16

function.name: gdk_memory_texture_builder_get_color_state
function.description:
Gets the colorstate previously set via gdk_memory_texture_builder_set_color_state().
Since: 4.16

function.name: gdk_memory_texture_builder_get_format
function.description:
Gets the format previously set via gdk_memory_texture_builder_set_format().
Since: 4.16

function.name: gdk_memory_texture_builder_get_height
function.description:
Gets the height previously set via gdk_memory_texture_builder_set_height() or 0 if the height wasn't set.
Since: 4.16

function.name: gdk_memory_texture_builder_get_stride
function.description:
Gets the stride previously set via gdk_memory_texture_builder_set_stride().
Since: 4.16

function.name: gdk_memory_texture_builder_get_update_region
function.description:
Gets the region previously set via gdk_memory_texture_builder_set_update_region() or %NULL if none was set.
Since: 4.16

function.name: gdk_memory_texture_builder_get_update_texture
function.description:
Gets the texture previously set via gdk_memory_texture_builder_set_update_texture() or %NULL if none was set.
Since: 4.16

function.name: gdk_memory_texture_builder_get_width
function.description:
Gets the width previously set via gdk_memory_texture_builder_set_width() or 0 if the width wasn't set.
Since: 4.16

function.name: gdk_memory_texture_builder_set_bytes
function.description:
Sets the data to be shown but the texture.
The bytes must be set before calling [method@Gdk.MemoryTextureBuilder.build].
Since: 4.16

parameter.name: bytes
parameter.parameter_description: The bytes the texture shows or %NULL to unset

function.name: gdk_memory_texture_builder_set_color_state
function.description:
Sets the colorstate describing the data.
By default, the sRGB colorstate is used. If you don't know what colorstates are, this is probably the right thing.
Since: 4.16

function.name: gdk_memory_texture_builder_set_format
function.description:
Sets the format of the bytes.
The default is `GDK_MEMORY_R8G8B8A8_PREMULTIPLIED`.
Since: 4.16

function.name: gdk_memory_texture_builder_set_height
function.description:
Sets the height of the texture.
The height must be set before calling [method@Gdk.MemoryTextureBuilder.build].
Since: 4.16

parameter.name: height
parameter.parameter_description: The texture's height or 0 to unset

function.name: gdk_memory_texture_builder_set_stride
function.description:
Sets the rowstride of the bytes used.
The rowstride must be set before calling [method@Gdk.MemoryTextureBuilder.build].
Since: 4.16

function.name: gdk_memory_texture_builder_set_update_region
function.description:
Sets the region to be updated by this texture.
Together with [property@Gdk.MemoryTextureBuilder:update-texture], this describes an update of a previous texture.
When rendering animations of large textures, it is possible that consecutive textures are only updating contents in parts of the texture. It is then possible to describe this update via these two properties, so that GTK can avoid rerendering parts that did not change.
An example would be a screen recording where only the mouse pointer moves.
Since: 4.16

function.name: gdk_memory_texture_builder_set_update_texture
function.description:
Sets the texture to be updated by this texture.
See [method@Gdk.MemoryTextureBuilder.set_update_region] for an explanation.
Since: 4.16

function.name: gdk_memory_texture_builder_set_width
function.description:
Sets the width of the texture.
The width must be set before calling [method@Gdk.MemoryTextureBuilder.build].
Since: 4.16

parameter.name: width
parameter.parameter_description: The texture's width or 0 to unset

function.name: gdk_memory_texture_new
function.description:
Creates a new texture for a blob of image data.
The `GBytes` must contain @stride × @height pixels in the given format.

function.name: gdk_monitor_get_connector
function.description:
Gets the name of the monitor's connector, if available.
These are strings such as "eDP-1", or "HDMI-2". They depend on software and hardware configuration, and should not be relied on as stable identifiers of a specific monitor.

function.name: gdk_monitor_get_description
function.description:
Gets a string describing the monitor, if available.
This can be used to identify a monitor in the UI.
Since: 4.10

function.name: gdk_monitor_get_display
function.description: Gets the display that this monitor belongs to.

function.name: gdk_monitor_get_geometry
function.description:
Retrieves the size and position of the monitor within the display coordinate space.
The returned geometry is in ”application pixels”, not in ”device pixels” (see [method@Gdk.Monitor.get_scale]).

parameter.name: geometry
parameter.parameter_description: a `GdkRectangle` to be filled with the monitor geometry

function.name: gdk_monitor_get_height_mm
function.description: Gets the height in millimeters of the monitor.
function.return: the physical height of the monitor

function.name: gdk_monitor_get_manufacturer
function.description:
Gets the name or PNP ID of the monitor's manufacturer.
Note that this value might also vary depending on actual display backend.
The PNP ID registry is located at [https://uefi.org/pnp_id_list](https://uefi.org/pnp_id_list).

function.name: gdk_monitor_get_model
function.description: Gets the string identifying the monitor model, if available.

function.name: gdk_monitor_get_refresh_rate
function.description:
Gets the refresh rate of the monitor, if available.
The value is in milli-Hertz, so a refresh rate of 60Hz is returned as 60000.
function.return: the refresh rate in milli-Hertz, or 0

function.name: gdk_monitor_get_scale
function.description:
Gets the internal scale factor that maps from monitor coordinates to device pixels.
This can be used if you want to create pixel based data for a particular monitor, but most of the time you’re drawing to a surface where it is better to use [method@Gdk.Surface.get_scale] instead.
Since: 4.14

function.name: gdk_monitor_get_scale_factor
function.description:
Gets the internal scale factor that maps from monitor coordinates to device pixels.
On traditional systems this is 1, but on very high density outputs it can be a higher value (often 2).
This can be used if you want to create pixel based data for a particular monitor, but most of the time you’re drawing to a surface where it is better to use [method@Gdk.Surface.get_scale_factor] instead.

function.name: gdk_monitor_get_subpixel_layout
function.description: Gets information about the layout of red, green and blue primaries for pixels.

function.name: gdk_monitor_get_width_mm
function.description: Gets the width in millimeters of the monitor.
function.return: the physical width of the monitor

function.name: gdk_monitor_is_valid
function.description:
Returns %TRUE if the @monitor object corresponds to a physical monitor.
The @monitor becomes invalid when the physical monitor is unplugged or removed.
function.return: %TRUE if the object corresponds to a physical monitor

function.name: gdk_pad_event_get_axis_value
function.description: Extracts the information from a pad strip or ring event.

parameter.name: event
parameter.parameter_description: a pad strip or ring event

parameter.name: index
parameter.parameter_description: Return location for the axis index

parameter.name: value
parameter.parameter_description: Return location for the axis value

function.name: gdk_pad_event_get_button
function.description: Extracts information about the pressed button from a pad event.

function.name: gdk_pad_event_get_group_mode
function.description: Extracts group and mode information from a pad event.

function.name: gdk_paintable_compute_concrete_size
function.description:
Compute a concrete size for the `GdkPaintable`.
Applies the sizing algorithm outlined in the [CSS Image spec](https://drafts.csswg.org/css-images-3/#default-sizing) to the given @paintable. See that link for more details.
It is not necessary to call this function when both @specified_width and @specified_height are known, but it is useful to call this function in GtkWidget:measure implementations to compute the other dimension when only one dimension is given.

parameter.name: specified_width
parameter.parameter_description: the width @paintable could be drawn into or 0.0 if unknown

parameter.name: specified_height
parameter.parameter_description: the height @paintable could be drawn into or 0.0 if unknown

parameter.name: default_width
parameter.parameter_description: the width @paintable would be drawn into if no other constraints were given

parameter.name: default_height
parameter.parameter_description: the height @paintable would be drawn into if no other constraints were given

parameter.name: concrete_width
parameter.parameter_description: will be set to the concrete width computed

parameter.name: concrete_height
parameter.parameter_description: will be set to the concrete height computed

function.name: gdk_paintable_get_current_image
function.description:
Gets an immutable paintable for the current contents displayed by @paintable.
This is useful when you want to retain the current state of an animation, for example to take a screenshot of a running animation.
If the @paintable is already immutable, it will return itself.
function.return: An immutable paintable for the current contents of @paintable

function.name: gdk_paintable_get_flags
function.description:
Get flags for the paintable.
This is oftentimes useful for optimizations.
See [flags@Gdk.PaintableFlags] for the flags and what they mean.

function.name: gdk_paintable_get_intrinsic_aspect_ratio
function.description:
Gets the preferred aspect ratio the @paintable would like to be displayed at.
The aspect ratio is the width divided by the height, so a value of 0.5 means that the @paintable prefers to be displayed twice as high as it is wide. Consumers of this interface can use this to preserve aspect ratio when displaying the paintable.
This is a purely informational value and does not in any way limit the values that may be passed to [method@Gdk.Paintable.snapshot].
Usually when a @paintable returns nonzero values from [method@Gdk.Paintable.get_intrinsic_width] and [method@Gdk.Paintable.get_intrinsic_height] the aspect ratio should conform to those values, though that is not required.
If the @paintable does not have a preferred aspect ratio, it returns 0. Negative values are never returned.
function.return: the intrinsic aspect ratio of @paintable or 0 if none.

function.name: gdk_paintable_get_intrinsic_height
function.description:
Gets the preferred height the @paintable would like to be displayed at.
Consumers of this interface can use this to reserve enough space to draw the paintable.
This is a purely informational value and does not in any way limit the values that may be passed to [method@Gdk.Paintable.snapshot].
If the @paintable does not have a preferred height, it returns 0. Negative values are never returned.
function.return: the intrinsic height of @paintable or 0 if none.

function.name: gdk_paintable_get_intrinsic_width
function.description:
Gets the preferred width the @paintable would like to be displayed at.
Consumers of this interface can use this to reserve enough space to draw the paintable.
This is a purely informational value and does not in any way limit the values that may be passed to [method@Gdk.Paintable.snapshot].
If the @paintable does not have a preferred width, it returns 0. Negative values are never returned.
function.return: the intrinsic width of @paintable or 0 if none.

function.name: gdk_paintable_invalidate_contents
function.description:
Called by implementations of `GdkPaintable` to invalidate their contents.
Unless the contents are invalidated, implementations must guarantee that multiple calls of [method@Gdk.Paintable.snapshot] produce the same output.
This function will emit the [signal@Gdk.Paintable::invalidate-contents] signal.
If a @paintable reports the %GDK_PAINTABLE_STATIC_CONTENTS flag, it must not call this function.

function.name: gdk_paintable_invalidate_size
function.description:
Called by implementations of `GdkPaintable` to invalidate their size.
As long as the size is not invalidated, @paintable must return the same values for its intrinsic width, height and aspect ratio.
This function will emit the [signal@Gdk.Paintable::invalidate-size] signal.
If a @paintable reports the %GDK_PAINTABLE_STATIC_SIZE flag, it must not call this function.

function.name: gdk_paintable_new_empty
function.description:
Returns a paintable that has the given intrinsic size and draws nothing.
This is often useful for implementing the [vfunc@Gdk.Paintable.get_current_image] virtual function when the paintable is in an incomplete state (like a [GtkMediaStream](../gtk4/class.MediaStream.html) before receiving the first frame).

parameter.name: intrinsic_width
parameter.parameter_description: The intrinsic width to report. Can be 0 for no width.

parameter.name: intrinsic_height
parameter.parameter_description: The intrinsic height to report. Can be 0 for no height.

function.name: gdk_paintable_snapshot
function.description:
Snapshots the given paintable with the given @width and @height.
The paintable is drawn at the current (0,0) offset of the @snapshot. If @width and @height are not larger than zero, this function will do nothing.

function.name: gdk_pango_layout_get_clip_region

parameter.name: x_origin
parameter.parameter_description: X pixel where you intend to draw the layout with this clip

parameter.name: y_origin
parameter.parameter_description: Y pixel where you intend to draw the layout with this clip

parameter.name: index_ranges
parameter.parameter_description: array of byte indexes into the layout, where even members of array are start indexes and odd elements are end indexes

parameter.name: n_ranges
parameter.parameter_description: number of ranges in @index_ranges, i.e. half the size of @index_ranges

function.return: a clip region containing the given ranges

function.name: gdk_pango_layout_line_get_clip_region

parameter.name: x_origin
parameter.parameter_description: X pixel where you intend to draw the layout line with this clip

parameter.name: y_origin
parameter.parameter_description: baseline pixel where you intend to draw the layout line with this clip

parameter.name: index_ranges
parameter.parameter_description: array of byte indexes into the layout, where even members of array are start indexes and odd elements are end indexes

parameter.name: n_ranges
parameter.parameter_description: number of ranges in @index_ranges, i.e. half the size of @index_ranges

function.return: a clip region containing the given ranges

function.name: gdk_parallel_task_run
function.description: Spawns the given function in many threads. Once all functions have exited, this function returns.

parameter.name: task_data
parameter.parameter_description: data to pass to the function

function.name: gdk_pipe_io_stream_new
function.description:
Creates a `GIOStream` whose input- and output-stream behave like a pipe.
Data written into the output stream becomes available for reading on the input stream.
Note that this is data transfer in the opposite direction to g_output_stream_splice().

function.name: gdk_pixbuf_add_alpha
function.description:
Takes an existing pixbuf and adds an alpha channel to it.
If the existing pixbuf already had an alpha channel, the channel values are copied from the original; otherwise, the alpha channel is initialized to 255 (full opacity).
If `substitute_color` is `TRUE`, then the color specified by the (`r`, `g`, `b`) arguments will be assigned zero opacity. That is, if you pass `(255, 255, 255)` for the substitute color, all white pixels will become fully transparent.
If `substitute_color` is `FALSE`, then the (`r`, `g`, `b`) arguments will be ignored.

parameter.name: substitute_color
parameter.parameter_description: Whether to set a color to zero opacity.

function.name: gdk_pixbuf_animation_get_height
function.description: Queries the height of the bounding box of a pixbuf animation.
function.return: Height of the bounding box of the animation.

function.name: gdk_pixbuf_animation_get_iter
function.description:
Get an iterator for displaying an animation.
The iterator provides the frames that should be displayed at a given time.
@start_time would normally come from g_get_current_time(), and marks the beginning of animation playback. After creating an iterator, you should immediately display the pixbuf returned by gdk_pixbuf_animation_iter_get_pixbuf(). Then, you should install a timeout (with g_timeout_add()) or by some other mechanism ensure that you'll update the image after gdk_pixbuf_animation_iter_get_delay_time() milliseconds. Each time the image is updated, you should reinstall the timeout with the new, possibly-changed delay time.
As a shortcut, if @start_time is `NULL`, the result of g_get_current_time() will be used automatically.
To update the image (i.e. possibly change the result of gdk_pixbuf_animation_iter_get_pixbuf() to a new frame of the animation), call gdk_pixbuf_animation_iter_advance().
If you're using #GdkPixbufLoader, in addition to updating the image after the delay time, you should also update it whenever you receive the area_updated signal and gdk_pixbuf_animation_iter_on_currently_loading_frame() returns `TRUE`. In this case, the frame currently being fed into the loader has received new data, so needs to be refreshed. The delay time for a frame may also be modified after an area_updated signal, for example if the delay time for a frame is encoded in the data after the frame itself. So your timeout should be reinstalled after any area_updated signal.
A delay time of -1 is possible, indicating "infinite".

parameter.name: start_time
parameter.parameter_description: time when the animation starts playing

function.return: an iterator to move over the animation

function.name: gdk_pixbuf_animation_get_static_image
function.description:
Retrieves a static image for the animation.
If an animation is really just a plain image (has only one frame), this function returns that image.
If the animation is an animation, this function returns a reasonable image to use as a static unanimated image, which might be the first frame, or something more sophisticated depending on the file format.
If an animation hasn't loaded any frames yet, this function will return `NULL`.

function.name: gdk_pixbuf_animation_get_width
function.description: Queries the width of the bounding box of a pixbuf animation.
function.return: Width of the bounding box of the animation.

function.name: gdk_pixbuf_animation_is_static_image
function.description:
Checks whether the animation is a static image.
If you load a file with gdk_pixbuf_animation_new_from_file() and it turns out to be a plain, unanimated image, then this function will return `TRUE`. Use gdk_pixbuf_animation_get_static_image() to retrieve the image.
function.return: `TRUE` if the "animation" was really just an image

function.name: gdk_pixbuf_animation_iter_advance
function.description:
Possibly advances an animation to a new frame.
Chooses the frame based on the start time passed to gdk_pixbuf_animation_get_iter().
@current_time would normally come from g_get_current_time(), and must be greater than or equal to the time passed to gdk_pixbuf_animation_get_iter(), and must increase or remain unchanged each time gdk_pixbuf_animation_iter_get_pixbuf() is called. That is, you can't go backward in time; animations only play forward.
As a shortcut, pass `NULL` for the current time and g_get_current_time() will be invoked on your behalf. So you only need to explicitly pass @current_time if you're doing something odd like playing the animation at double speed.
If this function returns `FALSE`, there's no need to update the animation display, assuming the display had been rendered prior to advancing; if `TRUE`, you need to call gdk_pixbuf_animation_iter_get_pixbuf() and update the display with the new pixbuf.
function.return: `TRUE` if the image may need updating

function.name: gdk_pixbuf_animation_iter_get_delay_time
function.description:
Gets the number of milliseconds the current pixbuf should be displayed, or -1 if the current pixbuf should be displayed forever.
The `g_timeout_add()` function conveniently takes a timeout in milliseconds, so you can use a timeout to schedule the next update.
Note that some formats, like GIF, might clamp the timeout values in the image file to avoid updates that are just too quick. The minimum timeout for GIF images is currently 20 milliseconds.
function.return: delay time in milliseconds (thousandths of a second)

function.name: gdk_pixbuf_animation_iter_get_pixbuf
function.description:
Gets the current pixbuf which should be displayed.
The pixbuf might not be the same size as the animation itself (gdk_pixbuf_animation_get_width(), gdk_pixbuf_animation_get_height()).
This pixbuf should be displayed for gdk_pixbuf_animation_iter_get_delay_time() milliseconds.
The caller of this function does not own a reference to the returned pixbuf; the returned pixbuf will become invalid when the iterator advances to the next frame, which may happen anytime you call gdk_pixbuf_animation_iter_advance().
Copy the pixbuf to keep it (don't just add a reference), as it may get recycled as you advance the iterator.

function.name: gdk_pixbuf_animation_iter_on_currently_loading_frame
function.description:
Used to determine how to respond to the area_updated signal on #GdkPixbufLoader when loading an animation.
The `::area_updated` signal is emitted for an area of the frame currently streaming in to the loader. So if you're on the currently loading frame, you will need to redraw the screen for the updated area.
function.return: `TRUE` if the frame we're on is partially loaded, or the last frame

function.name: gdk_pixbuf_animation_new_from_file
function.description:
Creates a new animation by loading it from a file.
The file format is detected automatically.
If the file's format does not support multi-frame images, then an animation with a single frame will be created.
Possible errors are in the `GDK_PIXBUF_ERROR` and `G_FILE_ERROR` domains.

parameter.name: filename
parameter.parameter_description: Name of file to load, in the GLib file name encoding

function.name: gdk_pixbuf_animation_new_from_file_utf8
function.description: Same as gdk_pixbuf_animation_new_from_file()

parameter.name: filename
parameter.parameter_description: Name of file to load, in the GLib file name encoding

function.return: A newly-created animation with a reference count of 1, or `NULL` if any of several error conditions ocurred: the file could not be opened, there was no loader for the file's format, there was not enough memory to allocate the image buffer, or the image file contained invalid data.

function.name: gdk_pixbuf_animation_new_from_resource
function.description:
Creates a new pixbuf animation by loading an image from an resource.
The file format is detected automatically. If `NULL` is returned, then @error will be set.
Since: 2.28

parameter.name: resource_path
parameter.parameter_description: the path of the resource file

function.name: gdk_pixbuf_animation_new_from_stream
function.description:
Creates a new animation by loading it from an input stream.
The file format is detected automatically.
If `NULL` is returned, then @error will be set.
The @cancellable can be used to abort the operation from another thread. If the operation was cancelled, the error `G_IO_ERROR_CANCELLED` will be returned. Other possible errors are in the `GDK_PIXBUF_ERROR` and `G_IO_ERROR` domains.
The stream is not closed.
Since: 2.28

parameter.name: stream
parameter.parameter_description: a `GInputStream` to load the pixbuf from

function.name: gdk_pixbuf_animation_new_from_stream_async
function.description:
Creates a new animation by asynchronously loading an image from an input stream.
For more details see gdk_pixbuf_new_from_stream(), which is the synchronous version of this function.
When the operation is finished, `callback` will be called in the main thread. You can then call gdk_pixbuf_animation_new_from_stream_finish() to get the result of the operation.
Since: 2.28

parameter.name: stream
parameter.parameter_description: a #GInputStream from which to load the animation

parameter.name: callback
parameter.parameter_description: a `GAsyncReadyCallback` to call when the pixbuf is loaded

parameter.name: user_data
parameter.parameter_description: the data to pass to the callback function

function.name: gdk_pixbuf_animation_new_from_stream_finish
function.description:
Finishes an asynchronous pixbuf animation creation operation started with [func@GdkPixbuf.PixbufAnimation.new_from_stream_async].
Since: 2.28

function.name: gdk_pixbuf_animation_ref
function.description:
Adds a reference to an animation.
Deprecated: 2.0: Use g_object_ref().

function.name: gdk_pixbuf_animation_unref
function.description:
Removes a reference from an animation.
Deprecated: 2.0: Use g_object_unref().

function.name: gdk_pixbuf_apply_embedded_orientation
function.description:
Takes an existing pixbuf and checks for the presence of an associated "orientation" option.
The orientation option may be provided by the JPEG loader (which reads the exif orientation tag) or the TIFF loader (which reads the TIFF orientation tag, and compensates it for the partial transforms performed by libtiff).
If an orientation option/tag is present, the appropriate transform will be performed so that the pixbuf is oriented correctly.
Return: (transfer full) (nullable): A newly-created pixbuf
Since: 2.12

parameter.name: src
parameter.parameter_description: a pixbuf with an orientation option

function.name: gdk_pixbuf_buffer_queue_clear
function.description: Resets @queue into to initial state. All buffers it contains will be released and the offset will be reset to 0.

function.name: gdk_pixbuf_buffer_queue_flush
function.description: Removes the first @n_bytes bytes from the queue.

parameter.name: n_bytes
parameter.parameter_description: amount of bytes to flush from the queue

function.name: gdk_pixbuf_buffer_queue_get_offset
function.description: Queries the amount of bytes that has already been pulled out of @queue using functions like gdk_pixbuf_buffer_queue_pull().
function.return: Number of bytes that were already pulled from this queue.

function.name: gdk_pixbuf_buffer_queue_get_size
function.description: Returns the number of bytes currently in @queue.

function.name: gdk_pixbuf_buffer_queue_new
function.description: Creates a new empty buffer queue.
function.return: a new buffer queue. Use gdk_pixbuf_buffer_queue_unref () to free it.

function.name: gdk_pixbuf_buffer_queue_peek
function.description: Creates a new buffer with the first @length bytes from @queue, but unlike gdk_pixbuf_buffer_queue_pull(), does not remove them from @queue.
function.return: NULL if the requested amount of data wasn't available or a new #GBytes. Use g_bytes_unref() after use.

function.name: gdk_pixbuf_buffer_queue_peek_buffer
function.description: Gets the first buffer out of @queue and returns it. This function is equivalent to calling gdk_pixbuf_buffer_queue_peek() with the size of the first buffer in it.
function.return: The first buffer in @queue or %NULL if @queue is empty. Use g_bytes_unref() after use.

function.name: gdk_pixbuf_buffer_queue_pull
function.description: If enough data is still available in @queue, the first @length bytes are put into a new buffer and that buffer is returned. The @length bytes are removed from the head of the queue. If not enough data is available, %NULL is returned.

function.name: gdk_pixbuf_buffer_queue_pull_buffer
function.description: Pulls the first buffer out of @queue and returns it. This function is equivalent to calling gdk_pixbuf_buffer_queue_pull() with the size of the first buffer in it.
function.return: The first buffer in @queue or %NULL if @queue is empty.

function.name: gdk_pixbuf_buffer_queue_push
function.description: Appends the given @bytes to the buffers already in @queue. This function will take ownership of the given @buffer. Use g_bytes_ref () before calling this function to keep a reference.

function.name: gdk_pixbuf_buffer_queue_ref
function.description: increases the reference count of @queue by one.

function.name: gdk_pixbuf_buffer_queue_unref
function.description: Decreases the reference count of @queue by one. If no reference to this buffer exists anymore, the buffer and the memory it manages are freed.

function.name: gdk_pixbuf_calculate_rowstride
function.description:
Calculates the rowstride that an image created with those values would have.
This function is useful for front-ends and backends that want to check image values without needing to create a `GdkPixbuf`.
Since: 2.36.8

parameter.name: has_alpha
parameter.parameter_description: Whether the image should have transparency information

parameter.name: bits_per_sample
parameter.parameter_description: Number of bits per color sample

parameter.name: width
parameter.parameter_description: Width of image in pixels, must be > 0

parameter.name: height
parameter.parameter_description: Height of image in pixels, must be > 0

function.return: the rowstride for the given values, or -1 in case of error.

function.name: gdk_pixbuf_composite
function.description:
Creates a transformation of the source image @src by scaling by @scale_x and @scale_y then translating by @offset_x and @offset_y.
This gives an image in the coordinates of the destination pixbuf. The rectangle (@dest_x, @dest_y, @dest_width, @dest_height) is then alpha blended onto the corresponding rectangle of the original destination image.
When the destination rectangle contains parts not in the source image, the data at the edges of the source image is replicated to infinity.
![](composite.png)

parameter.name: dest
parameter.parameter_description: the #GdkPixbuf into which to render the results

parameter.name: dest_x
parameter.parameter_description: the left coordinate for region to render

parameter.name: dest_y
parameter.parameter_description: the top coordinate for region to render

parameter.name: dest_width
parameter.parameter_description: the width of the region to render

parameter.name: dest_height
parameter.parameter_description: the height of the region to render

parameter.name: offset_x
parameter.parameter_description: the offset in the X direction (currently rounded to an integer)

parameter.name: offset_y
parameter.parameter_description: the offset in the Y direction (currently rounded to an integer)

parameter.name: scale_x
parameter.parameter_description: the scale factor in the X direction

parameter.name: scale_y
parameter.parameter_description: the scale factor in the Y direction

parameter.name: interp_type
parameter.parameter_description: the interpolation type for the transformation.

function.name: gdk_pixbuf_composite_color
function.description:
Creates a transformation of the source image @src by scaling by @scale_x and @scale_y then translating by @offset_x and @offset_y, then alpha blends the rectangle (@dest_x ,@dest_y, @dest_width, @dest_height) of the resulting image with a checkboard of the colors @color1 and @color2 and renders it onto the destination image.
If the source image has no alpha channel, and @overall_alpha is 255, a fast path is used which omits the alpha blending and just performs the scaling.
See gdk_pixbuf_composite_color_simple() for a simpler variant of this function suitable for many tasks.

parameter.name: dest
parameter.parameter_description: the #GdkPixbuf into which to render the results

parameter.name: dest_x
parameter.parameter_description: the left coordinate for region to render

parameter.name: dest_y
parameter.parameter_description: the top coordinate for region to render

parameter.name: dest_width
parameter.parameter_description: the width of the region to render

parameter.name: dest_height
parameter.parameter_description: the height of the region to render

parameter.name: offset_x
parameter.parameter_description: the offset in the X direction (currently rounded to an integer)

parameter.name: offset_y
parameter.parameter_description: the offset in the Y direction (currently rounded to an integer)

parameter.name: scale_x
parameter.parameter_description: the scale factor in the X direction

parameter.name: scale_y
parameter.parameter_description: the scale factor in the Y direction

parameter.name: interp_type
parameter.parameter_description: the interpolation type for the transformation.

parameter.name: check_x
parameter.parameter_description: the X offset for the checkboard (origin of checkboard is at -@check_x, -@check_y)

parameter.name: check_y
parameter.parameter_description: the Y offset for the checkboard

parameter.name: check_size
parameter.parameter_description: the size of checks in the checkboard (must be a power of two)

parameter.name: color1
parameter.parameter_description: the color of check at upper left

parameter.name: color2
parameter.parameter_description: the color of the other check

function.name: gdk_pixbuf_composite_color_simple
function.description: Creates a new pixbuf by scaling `src` to `dest_width` x `dest_height` and alpha blending the result with a checkboard of colors `color1` and `color2`.

parameter.name: interp_type
parameter.parameter_description: the interpolation type for the transformation.

parameter.name: check_size
parameter.parameter_description: the size of checks in the checkboard (must be a power of two)

parameter.name: color1
parameter.parameter_description: the color of check at upper left

parameter.name: color2
parameter.parameter_description: the color of the other check

function.name: gdk_pixbuf_copy
function.description:
Creates a new `GdkPixbuf` with a copy of the information in the specified `pixbuf`.
Note that this does not copy the options set on the original `GdkPixbuf`, use gdk_pixbuf_copy_options() for this.

function.name: gdk_pixbuf_copy_area
function.description:
Copies a rectangular area from `src_pixbuf` to `dest_pixbuf`.
Conversion of pixbuf formats is done automatically.
If the source rectangle overlaps the destination rectangle on the same pixbuf, it will be overwritten during the copy operation. Therefore, you can not use this function to scroll a pixbuf.

parameter.name: width
parameter.parameter_description: Width of the area to copy.

parameter.name: height
parameter.parameter_description: Height of the area to copy.

function.name: gdk_pixbuf_copy_options
function.description:
Copies the key/value pair options attached to a `GdkPixbuf` to another `GdkPixbuf`.
This is useful to keep original metadata after having manipulated a file. However be careful to remove metadata which you've already applied, such as the "orientation" option after rotating the image.
Since: 2.36

function.name: gdk_pixbuf_fill
function.description:
Clears a pixbuf to the given RGBA value, converting the RGBA value into the pixbuf's pixel format.
The alpha component will be ignored if the pixbuf doesn't have an alpha channel.

parameter.name: pixel
parameter.parameter_description: RGBA pixel to used to clear (`0xffffffff` is opaque white, `0x00000000` transparent black)

function.name: gdk_pixbuf_flip
function.description:
Flips a pixbuf horizontally or vertically and returns the result in a new pixbuf.
Since: 2.6

parameter.name: horizontal
parameter.parameter_description: `TRUE` to flip horizontally, `FALSE` to flip vertically

function.name: gdk_pixbuf_format_copy
function.description:
Creates a copy of `format`.
Since: 2.22
function.return: the newly allocated copy of a `GdkPixbufFormat`. Use gdk_pixbuf_format_free() to free the resources when done

function.name: gdk_pixbuf_format_free
gdk_pixbuf_format_get_description
function.description:
Returns a description of the format.
Since: 2.2

function.name: gdk_pixbuf_format_get_extensions
function.description:
Returns the filename extensions typically used for files in the given format.
Since: 2.2

function.name: gdk_pixbuf_format_get_license
function.description:
Returns information about the license of the image loader for the format.
The returned string should be a shorthand for a well known license, e.g. "LGPL", "GPL", "QPL", "GPL/QPL", or "other" to indicate some other license.
Since: 2.6
function.return: a string describing the license of the pixbuf format

function.name: gdk_pixbuf_format_get_mime_types
function.description:
Returns the mime types supported by the format.
Since: 2.2

function.name: gdk_pixbuf_format_get_name
function.description:
Returns the name of the format.
Since: 2.2

function.name: gdk_pixbuf_format_is_disabled
function.description:
Returns whether this image format is disabled.
See gdk_pixbuf_format_set_disabled().
Since: 2.6
function.return: whether this image format is disabled.

function.name: gdk_pixbuf_format_is_save_option_supported
function.description:
Returns `TRUE` if the save option specified by @option_key is supported when saving a pixbuf using the module implementing @format.
See gdk_pixbuf_save() for more information about option keys.
Since: 2.36
function.return: `TRUE` if the specified option is supported

function.name: gdk_pixbuf_format_is_scalable
function.description:
Returns whether this image format is scalable.
If a file is in a scalable format, it is preferable to load it at the desired size, rather than loading it at the default size and scaling the resulting pixbuf to the desired size.
Since: 2.6
function.return: whether this image format is scalable.

function.name: gdk_pixbuf_format_is_writable
function.description:
Returns whether pixbufs can be saved in the given format.
Since: 2.2
function.return: whether pixbufs can be saved in the given format.

function.name: gdk_pixbuf_format_set_disabled
function.description:
Disables or enables an image format.
If a format is disabled, GdkPixbuf won't use the image loader for this format to load images.
Applications can use this to avoid using image loaders with an inappropriate license, see gdk_pixbuf_format_get_license().
Since: 2.6

function.name: gdk_pixbuf_from_pixdata
function.description:
Converts a `GdkPixdata` to a `GdkPixbuf`.
If `copy_pixels` is `TRUE` or if the pixel data is run-length-encoded, the pixel data is copied into newly-allocated memory; otherwise it is reused.
Deprecated: 2.32: Use `GResource` instead.

parameter.name: copy_pixels
parameter.parameter_description: whether to copy raw pixel data; run-length encoded pixel data is always copied.

function.name: gdk_pixbuf_get_bits_per_sample
function.description: Queries the number of bits per color sample in a pixbuf.
function.return: Number of bits per color sample.

function.name: gdk_pixbuf_get_byte_length
function.description:
Returns the length of the pixel data, in bytes.
Since: 2.26
function.return: The length of the pixel data.

function.name: gdk_pixbuf_get_colorspace
function.description: Queries the color space of a pixbuf.

function.name: gdk_pixbuf_get_file_info
function.description:
Parses an image file far enough to determine its format and size.
Since: 2.4

parameter.name: filename
parameter.parameter_description: The name of the file to identify.

parameter.name: width
parameter.parameter_description: Return location for the width of the image

parameter.name: height
parameter.parameter_description: Return location for the height of the image

function.return: A `GdkPixbufFormat` describing the image format of the file

function.name: gdk_pixbuf_get_file_info_async
function.description:
Asynchronously parses an image file far enough to determine its format and size.
For more details see gdk_pixbuf_get_file_info(), which is the synchronous version of this function.
When the operation is finished, @callback will be called in the main thread. You can then call gdk_pixbuf_get_file_info_finish() to get the result of the operation.
Since: 2.32

parameter.name: filename
parameter.parameter_description: The name of the file to identify

parameter.name: callback
parameter.parameter_description: a `GAsyncReadyCallback` to call when the file info is available

parameter.name: user_data
parameter.parameter_description: the data to pass to the callback function

function.name: gdk_pixbuf_get_file_info_finish
function.description:
Finishes an asynchronous pixbuf parsing operation started with gdk_pixbuf_get_file_info_async().
Since: 2.32

parameter.name: width
parameter.parameter_description: Return location for the width of the image, or `NULL`

parameter.name: height
parameter.parameter_description: Return location for the height of the image, or `NULL`

function.return: A `GdkPixbufFormat` describing the image format of the file

function.name: gdk_pixbuf_get_formats
function.description:
Obtains the available information about the image formats supported by GdkPixbuf.
Since: 2.2
function.return: A list of support image formats.

function.name: gdk_pixbuf_get_from_surface
function.description:
Transfers image data from a `cairo_surface_t` and converts it to a `GdkPixbuf`.
This allows you to efficiently read individual pixels from cairo surfaces.
This function will create an RGB pixbuf with 8 bits per channel. The pixbuf will contain an alpha channel if the @surface contains one.
Deprecated: 4.12: Use [class@Gdk.Texture] and subclasses instead cairo surfaces and pixbufs

parameter.name: width
parameter.parameter_description: Width in pixels of region to get

parameter.name: height
parameter.parameter_description: Height in pixels of region to get

function.return: A newly-created pixbuf with a reference count of 1

function.name: gdk_pixbuf_get_from_texture
function.description:
Creates a new pixbuf from @texture.
This should generally not be used in newly written code as later stages will almost certainly convert the pixbuf back into a texture to draw it on screen.
Deprecated: 4.12: Use [class@Gdk.Texture] and subclasses instead cairo surfaces and pixbufs

function.name: gdk_pixbuf_get_has_alpha
function.description: Queries whether a pixbuf has an alpha channel (opacity information).
function.return: `TRUE` if it has an alpha channel, `FALSE` otherwise.

function.name: gdk_pixbuf_get_height
function.description: Queries the height of a pixbuf.

function.name: gdk_pixbuf_get_n_channels
function.description: Queries the number of channels of a pixbuf.

function.name: gdk_pixbuf_get_option
function.description:
Looks up @key in the list of options that may have been attached to the @pixbuf when it was loaded, or that may have been attached by another function using gdk_pixbuf_set_option().
For instance, the ANI loader provides "Title" and "Artist" options. The ICO, XBM, and XPM loaders provide "x_hot" and "y_hot" hot-spot options for cursor definitions. The PNG loader provides the tEXt ancillary chunk key/value pairs as options. Since 2.12, the TIFF and JPEG loaders return an "orientation" option string that corresponds to the embedded TIFF/Exif orientation tag (if present). Since 2.32, the TIFF loader sets the "multipage" option string to "yes" when a multi-page TIFF is loaded. Since 2.32 the JPEG and PNG loaders set "x-dpi" and "y-dpi" if the file contains image density information in dots per inch. Since 2.36.6, the JPEG loader sets the "comment" option with the comment EXIF tag.

function.name: gdk_pixbuf_get_options
function.description:
Returns a `GHashTable` with a list of all the options that may have been attached to the `pixbuf` when it was loaded, or that may have been attached by another function using [method@GdkPixbuf.Pixbuf.set_option].
Since: 2.32

function.name: gdk_pixbuf_get_pixels
function.description:
Queries a pointer to the pixel data of a pixbuf.
This function will cause an implicit copy of the pixbuf data if the pixbuf was created from read-only data.
Please see the section on [image data](class.Pixbuf.html#image-data) for information about how the pixel data is stored in memory.
function.return: A pointer to the pixbuf's pixel data.

function.name: gdk_pixbuf_get_pixels_with_length
function.description:
Queries a pointer to the pixel data of a pixbuf.
This function will cause an implicit copy of the pixbuf data if the pixbuf was created from read-only data.
Please see the section on [image data](class.Pixbuf.html#image-data) for information about how the pixel data is stored in memory.
Since: 2.26

parameter.name: length
parameter.parameter_description: The length of the binary data.

function.return: A pointer to the pixbuf's pixel data.

function.name: gdk_pixbuf_get_rowstride
function.description: Queries the rowstride of a pixbuf, which is the number of bytes between the start of a row and the start of the next row.

function.name: gdk_pixbuf_get_width
function.description: Queries the width of a pixbuf.

function.name: gdk_pixbuf_init_modules
function.description:
Initalizes the gdk-pixbuf loader modules referenced by the `loaders.cache` file present inside that directory.
This is to be used by applications that want to ship certain loaders in a different location from the system ones.
This is needed when the OS or runtime ships a minimal number of loaders so as to reduce the potential attack surface of carefully crafted image files, especially for uncommon file types. Applications that require broader image file types coverage, such as image viewers, would be expected to ship the gdk-pixbuf modules in a separate location, bundled with the application in a separate directory from the OS or runtime- provided modules.
Since: 2.40

parameter.name: path
parameter.parameter_description: Path to directory where the `loaders.cache` is installed

function.name: gdk_pixbuf_loader_close
function.description:
Informs a pixbuf loader that no further writes with gdk_pixbuf_loader_write() will occur, so that it can free its internal loading structures.
This function also tries to parse any data that hasn't yet been parsed; if the remaining data is partial or corrupt, an error will be returned.
If `FALSE` is returned, `error` will be set to an error from the `GDK_PIXBUF_ERROR` or `G_FILE_ERROR` domains.
If you're just cancelling a load rather than expecting it to be finished, passing `NULL` for `error` to ignore it is reasonable.
Remember that this function does not release a reference on the loader, so you will need to explicitly release any reference you hold.

parameter.name: error
parameter.parameter_description: return location for a #GError, or `NULL` to ignore errors

function.return: `TRUE` if all image data written so far was successfully passed out via the update_area signal

function.name: gdk_pixbuf_loader_get_animation
function.description:
Queries the #GdkPixbufAnimation that a pixbuf loader is currently creating.
In general it only makes sense to call this function after the [signal@GdkPixbuf.PixbufLoader::area-prepared] signal has been emitted by the loader.
If the loader doesn't have enough bytes yet, and hasn't emitted the `area-prepared` signal, this function will return `NULL`.
function.return: The animation that the loader is currently loading

function.name: gdk_pixbuf_loader_get_format
function.description:
Obtains the available information about the format of the currently loading image file.
Since: 2.2

function.name: gdk_pixbuf_loader_get_pixbuf
function.description:
Queries the #GdkPixbuf that a pixbuf loader is currently creating.
In general it only makes sense to call this function after the [signal@GdkPixbuf.PixbufLoader::area-prepared] signal has been emitted by the loader; this means that enough data has been read to know the size of the image that will be allocated.
If the loader has not received enough data via gdk_pixbuf_loader_write(), then this function returns `NULL`.
The returned pixbuf will be the same in all future calls to the loader, so if you want to keep using it, you should acquire a reference to it.
Additionally, if the loader is an animation, it will return the "static image" of the animation (see gdk_pixbuf_animation_get_static_image()).
function.return: The pixbuf that the loader is creating

function.name: gdk_pixbuf_loader_new
function.description: Creates a new pixbuf loader object.

function.name: gdk_pixbuf_loader_new_with_mime_type
function.description:
Creates a new pixbuf loader object that always attempts to parse image data as if it were an image of MIME type @mime_type, instead of identifying the type automatically.
This function is useful if you want an error if the image isn't the expected MIME type; for loading image formats that can't be reliably identified by looking at the data; or if the user manually forces a specific MIME type.
The list of supported mime types depends on what image loaders are installed, but typically "image/png", "image/jpeg", "image/gif", "image/tiff" and "image/x-xpixmap" are among the supported mime types. To obtain the full list of supported mime types, call gdk_pixbuf_format_get_mime_types() on each of the #GdkPixbufFormat structs returned by gdk_pixbuf_get_formats().
Since: 2.4

parameter.name: mime_type
parameter.parameter_description: the mime type to be loaded

parameter.name: error
parameter.parameter_description: return location for an allocated #GError, or `NULL` to ignore errors

function.name: gdk_pixbuf_loader_new_with_type
function.description:
Creates a new pixbuf loader object that always attempts to parse image data as if it were an image of type @image_type, instead of identifying the type automatically.
This function is useful if you want an error if the image isn't the expected type; for loading image formats that can't be reliably identified by looking at the data; or if the user manually forces a specific type.
The list of supported image formats depends on what image loaders are installed, but typically "png", "jpeg", "gif", "tiff" and "xpm" are among the supported formats. To obtain the full list of supported image formats, call gdk_pixbuf_format_get_name() on each of the #GdkPixbufFormat structs returned by gdk_pixbuf_get_formats().

parameter.name: image_type
parameter.parameter_description: name of the image format to be loaded with the image

parameter.name: error
parameter.parameter_description: return location for an allocated #GError, or `NULL` to ignore errors

function.name: gdk_pixbuf_loader_set_size
function.description:
Causes the image to be scaled while it is loaded.
The desired image size can be determined relative to the original size of the image by calling gdk_pixbuf_loader_set_size() from a signal handler for the ::size-prepared signal.
Attempts to set the desired image size are ignored after the emission of the ::size-prepared signal.
Since: 2.2

parameter.name: width
parameter.parameter_description: The desired width of the image being loaded.

parameter.name: height
parameter.parameter_description: The desired height of the image being loaded.

function.name: gdk_pixbuf_loader_write
function.description: Parses the next `count` bytes in the given image buffer.

parameter.name: count
parameter.parameter_description: Length of the @buf buffer in bytes.

function.return: `TRUE` if the write was successful, or `FALSE` if the loader cannot parse the buffer

function.name: gdk_pixbuf_loader_write_bytes
function.description:
Parses the next contents of the given image buffer.
Since: 2.30

parameter.name: buffer
parameter.parameter_description: The image data as a `GBytes` buffer.

function.return: `TRUE` if the write was successful, or `FALSE` if the loader cannot parse the buffer

function.name: gdk_pixbuf_major_version
function.description:
The major version number of the gdk-pixbuf library. (e.g. in gdk-pixbuf version 1.2.5 this is 1.)
This variable is in the library, so represents the gdk-pixbuf library you have linked against. Contrast with the `GDK_PIXBUF_MAJOR` macro, which represents the major version of the gdk-pixbuf headers you have included.

function.name: gdk_pixbuf_micro_version
function.description:
The micro version number of the gdk-pixbuf library. (e.g. in gdk-pixbuf version 1.2.5 this is 5.)
This variable is in the library, so represents the gdk-pixbuf library you have linked against. Contrast with the `GDK_PIXBUF_MICRO` macro, which represents the micro version of the gdk-pixbuf headers you have included.

function.name: gdk_pixbuf_minor_version
function.description:
The minor version number of the gdk-pixbuf library. (e.g. in gdk-pixbuf version 1.2.5 this is 2.)
This variable is in the library, so represents the gdk-pixbuf library you have linked against. Contrast with the `GDK_PIXBUF_MINOR` macro, which represents the minor version of the gdk-pixbuf headers you have included.

function.name: gdk_pixbuf_new
function.description:
Creates a new `GdkPixbuf` structure and allocates a buffer for it.
If the allocation of the buffer failed, this function will return `NULL`.
The buffer has an optimal rowstride. Note that the buffer is not cleared; you will have to fill it completely yourself.

parameter.name: has_alpha
parameter.parameter_description: Whether the image should have transparency information

parameter.name: bits_per_sample
parameter.parameter_description: Number of bits per color sample

parameter.name: width
parameter.parameter_description: Width of image in pixels, must be > 0

parameter.name: height
parameter.parameter_description: Height of image in pixels, must be > 0

function.name: gdk_pixbuf_new_from_bytes
function.description:
Creates a new #GdkPixbuf out of in-memory readonly image data.
Currently only RGB images with 8 bits per sample are supported.
This is the `GBytes` variant of gdk_pixbuf_new_from_data(), useful for language bindings.
Since: 2.32

parameter.name: data
parameter.parameter_description: Image data in 8-bit/sample packed format inside a #GBytes

parameter.name: has_alpha
parameter.parameter_description: Whether the data has an opacity channel

parameter.name: width
parameter.parameter_description: Width of the image in pixels, must be > 0

parameter.name: height
parameter.parameter_description: Height of the image in pixels, must be > 0

parameter.name: rowstride
parameter.parameter_description: Distance in bytes between row starts

function.name: gdk_pixbuf_new_from_data
function.description:
Creates a new #GdkPixbuf out of in-memory image data.
Currently only RGB images with 8 bits per sample are supported.
Since you are providing a pre-allocated pixel buffer, you must also specify a way to free that data. This is done with a function of type `GdkPixbufDestroyNotify`. When a pixbuf created with is finalized, your destroy notification function will be called, and it is its responsibility to free the pixel array.
See also: [ctor@GdkPixbuf.Pixbuf.new_from_bytes]

parameter.name: has_alpha
parameter.parameter_description: Whether the data has an opacity channel

parameter.name: width
parameter.parameter_description: Width of the image in pixels, must be > 0

parameter.name: height
parameter.parameter_description: Height of the image in pixels, must be > 0

parameter.name: rowstride
parameter.parameter_description: Distance in bytes between row starts

parameter.name: destroy_fn
parameter.parameter_description: Function used to free the data when the pixbuf's reference count drops to zero, or %NULL if the data should not be freed

parameter.name: destroy_fn_data
parameter.parameter_description: Closure data to pass to the destroy notification function

function.name: gdk_pixbuf_new_from_file
function.description:
Creates a new pixbuf by loading an image from a file.
The file format is detected automatically.
If `NULL` is returned, then @error will be set. Possible errors are:
- the file could not be opened - there is no loader for the file's format - there is not enough memory to allocate the image buffer - the image buffer contains invalid data
The error domains are `GDK_PIXBUF_ERROR` and `G_FILE_ERROR`.

parameter.name: filename
parameter.parameter_description: Name of file to load, in the GLib file name encoding

function.name: gdk_pixbuf_new_from_file_at_scale
function.description:
Creates a new pixbuf by loading an image from a file.
The file format is detected automatically.
If `NULL` is returned, then @error will be set. Possible errors are:
- the file could not be opened - there is no loader for the file's format - there is not enough memory to allocate the image buffer - the image buffer contains invalid data
The error domains are `GDK_PIXBUF_ERROR` and `G_FILE_ERROR`.
The image will be scaled to fit in the requested size, optionally preserving the image's aspect ratio.
When preserving the aspect ratio, a `width` of -1 will cause the image to be scaled to the exact given height, and a `height` of -1 will cause the image to be scaled to the exact given width. When not preserving aspect ratio, a `width` or `height` of -1 means to not scale the image at all in that dimension. Negative values for `width` and `height` are allowed since 2.8.
Since: 2.6

parameter.name: filename
parameter.parameter_description: Name of file to load, in the GLib file name encoding

parameter.name: width
parameter.parameter_description: The width the image should have or -1 to not constrain the width

parameter.name: height
parameter.parameter_description: The height the image should have or -1 to not constrain the height

parameter.name: preserve_aspect_ratio
parameter.parameter_description: `TRUE` to preserve the image's aspect ratio

function.name: gdk_pixbuf_new_from_file_at_scale_utf8
function.description:
Same as gdk_pixbuf_new_from_file_at_scale().
Since: 2.6

parameter.name: filename
parameter.parameter_description: Name of file to load, in the GLib file name encoding

parameter.name: width
parameter.parameter_description: The width the image should have or -1 to not constrain the width

parameter.name: height
parameter.parameter_description: The height the image should have or -1 to not constrain the height

parameter.name: preserve_aspect_ratio
parameter.parameter_description: `TRUE` to preserve the image's aspect ratio

function.return: A newly-created pixbuf with a reference count of 1, or `NULL` if any of several error conditions occurred: the file could not be opened, there was no loader for the file's format, there was not enough memory to allocate the image buffer, or the image file contained invalid data.

function.name: gdk_pixbuf_new_from_file_at_size
function.description:
Creates a new pixbuf by loading an image from a file.
The file format is detected automatically.
If `NULL` is returned, then @error will be set. Possible errors are:
- the file could not be opened - there is no loader for the file's format - there is not enough memory to allocate the image buffer - the image buffer contains invalid data
The error domains are `GDK_PIXBUF_ERROR` and `G_FILE_ERROR`.
The image will be scaled to fit in the requested size, preserving the image's aspect ratio. Note that the returned pixbuf may be smaller than `width` x `height`, if the aspect ratio requires it. To load and image at the requested size, regardless of aspect ratio, use [ctor@GdkPixbuf.Pixbuf.new_from_file_at_scale].
Since: 2.4

parameter.name: filename
parameter.parameter_description: Name of file to load, in the GLib file name encoding

parameter.name: width
parameter.parameter_description: The width the image should have or -1 to not constrain the width

parameter.name: height
parameter.parameter_description: The height the image should have or -1 to not constrain the height

function.name: gdk_pixbuf_new_from_file_at_size_utf8
function.description:
Same as gdk_pixbuf_new_from_file_at_size()
Since: 2.4

parameter.name: filename
parameter.parameter_description: Name of file to load, in the GLib file name encoding

parameter.name: width
parameter.parameter_description: The width the image should have or -1 to not constrain the width

parameter.name: height
