function.return: %TRUE if @layout and @other have identical layout properties, otherwise %FALSE.

function.name: gdk_popup_layout_get_anchor_hints
function.description: Get the `GdkAnchorHints`.

function.name: gdk_popup_layout_get_anchor_rect
function.description: Get the anchor rectangle.

function.name: gdk_popup_layout_get_offset
function.description: Retrieves the offset for the anchor rectangle.

parameter.name: dx
parameter.parameter_description: return location for the delta X coordinate

parameter.name: dy
parameter.parameter_description: return location for the delta Y coordinate

function.name: gdk_popup_layout_get_rect_anchor
function.description: Returns the anchor position on the anchor rectangle.
function.return: the anchor on the anchor rectangle.

function.name: gdk_popup_layout_get_shadow_width
function.description:
Obtains the shadow widths of this layout.
Since: 4.2

parameter.name: left
parameter.parameter_description: return location for the left shadow width

parameter.name: right
parameter.parameter_description: return location for the right shadow width

parameter.name: top
parameter.parameter_description: return location for the top shadow width

parameter.name: bottom
parameter.parameter_description: return location for the bottom shadow width

function.name: gdk_popup_layout_get_surface_anchor
function.description: Returns the anchor position on the popup surface.
function.return: the anchor on the popup surface.

function.name: gdk_popup_layout_new
function.description:
Create a popup layout description.
Used together with [method@Gdk.Popup.present] to describe how a popup surface should be placed and behave on-screen.
@anchor_rect is relative to the top-left corner of the surface's parent. @rect_anchor and @surface_anchor determine anchor points on @anchor_rect and surface to pin together.
The position of @anchor_rect's anchor point can optionally be offset using [method@Gdk.PopupLayout.set_offset], which is equivalent to offsetting the position of surface.

parameter.name: rect_anchor
parameter.parameter_description: the point on @anchor_rect to align with @surface's anchor point

parameter.name: surface_anchor
parameter.parameter_description: the point on @surface to align with @rect's anchor point

function.name: gdk_popup_layout_ref
function.description: Increases the reference count of @value.

function.name: gdk_popup_layout_set_anchor_hints
function.description:
Set new anchor hints.
The set @anchor_hints determines how @surface will be moved if the anchor points cause it to move off-screen. For example, %GDK_ANCHOR_FLIP_X will replace %GDK_GRAVITY_NORTH_WEST with %GDK_GRAVITY_NORTH_EAST and vice versa if @surface extends beyond the left or right edges of the monitor.

function.name: gdk_popup_layout_set_anchor_rect
function.description: Set the anchor rectangle.

function.name: gdk_popup_layout_set_offset
function.description: Offset the position of the anchor rectangle with the given delta.

parameter.name: dx
parameter.parameter_description: x delta to offset the anchor rectangle with

parameter.name: dy
parameter.parameter_description: y delta to offset the anchor rectangle with

function.name: gdk_popup_layout_set_rect_anchor
function.description: Set the anchor on the anchor rectangle.

function.name: gdk_popup_layout_set_shadow_width
function.description:
Sets the shadow width of the popup.
The shadow width corresponds to the part of the computed surface size that would consist of the shadow margin surrounding the window, would there be any.
Since: 4.2

parameter.name: left
parameter.parameter_description: width of the left part of the shadow

parameter.name: right
parameter.parameter_description: width of the right part of the shadow

parameter.name: top
parameter.parameter_description: height of the top part of the shadow

parameter.name: bottom
parameter.parameter_description: height of the bottom part of the shadow

function.name: gdk_popup_layout_set_surface_anchor
function.description: Set the anchor on the popup surface.

function.name: gdk_popup_layout_unref
function.description: Decreases the reference count of @value.

function.name: gdk_popup_present
function.description:
Present @popup after having processed the `GdkPopupLayout` rules.
If the popup was previously not showing, it will be shown, otherwise it will change position according to @layout.
After calling this function, the result should be handled in response to the [signal@Gdk.Surface::layout] signal being emitted. The resulting popup position can be queried using [method@Gdk.Popup.get_position_x], [method@Gdk.Popup.get_position_y], and the resulting size will be sent as parameters in the layout signal. Use [method@Gdk.Popup.get_rect_anchor] and [method@Gdk.Popup.get_surface_anchor] to get the resulting anchors.
Presenting may fail, for example if the @popup is set to autohide and is immediately hidden upon being presented. If presenting failed, the [signal@Gdk.Surface::layout] signal will not me emitted.

parameter.name: width
parameter.parameter_description: the unconstrained popup width to layout

parameter.name: height
parameter.parameter_description: the unconstrained popup height to layout

function.return: %FALSE if it failed to be presented, otherwise %TRUE.

function.name: gdk_rectangle_contains_point
function.description: Returns %TRUE if @rect contains the point described by @x and @y.

function.name: gdk_rectangle_equal
function.description: Checks if the two given rectangles are equal.

function.name: gdk_rectangle_intersect
function.description:
Calculates the intersection of two rectangles.
It is allowed for @dest to be the same as either @src1 or @src2. If the rectangles do not intersect, @dest’s width and height is set to 0 and its x and y values are undefined. If you are only interested in whether the rectangles intersect, but not in the intersecting area itself, pass %NULL for @dest.

parameter.name: dest
parameter.parameter_description: return location for the intersection of @src1 and @src2

function.name: gdk_rectangle_union
function.description:
Calculates the union of two rectangles.
The union of rectangles @src1 and @src2 is the smallest rectangle which includes both @src1 and @src2 within it. It is allowed for @dest to be the same as either @src1 or @src2.
Note that this function does not ignore 'empty' rectangles (ie. with zero width or height).

parameter.name: dest
parameter.parameter_description: return location for the union of @src1 and @src2

function.name: gdk_rgba_copy
function.description:
Makes a copy of a `GdkRGBA`.
The result must be freed through [method@Gdk.RGBA.free].
function.return: A newly allocated `GdkRGBA`, with the same contents as @rgba

function.name: gdk_rgba_equal
function.description: Compares two `GdkRGBA` colors.
function.return: %TRUE if the two colors compare equal

function.name: gdk_rgba_free
function.description: Frees a `GdkRGBA`.

function.name: gdk_rgba_hash
function.description: A hash function suitable for using for a hash table that stores `GdkRGBA`s.

function.name: gdk_rgba_is_clear
function.description:
Checks if an @rgba value is transparent.
That is, drawing with the value would not produce any change.

function.name: gdk_rgba_is_opaque
function.description:
Checks if an @rgba value is opaque.
That is, drawing with the value will not retain any results from previous contents.

function.name: gdk_rgba_parse
function.description:
Parses a textual representation of a color.
The string can be either one of:
- A standard name (Taken from the CSS specification). - A hexadecimal value in the form “\#rgb”, “\#rrggbb”, “\#rrrgggbbb” or ”\#rrrrggggbbbb” - A hexadecimal value in the form “\#rgba”, “\#rrggbbaa”, or ”\#rrrrggggbbbbaaaa” - A RGB color in the form “rgb(r,g,b)” (In this case the color will have full opacity) - A RGBA color in the form “rgba(r,g,b,a)” - A HSL color in the form "hsl(hue, saturation, lightness)" - A HSLA color in the form "hsla(hue, saturation, lightness, alpha)"
Where “r”, “g”, “b” and “a” are respectively the red, green, blue and alpha color values. In the last two cases, “r”, “g”, and “b” are either integers in the range 0 to 255 or percentage values in the range 0% to 100%, and a is a floating point value in the range 0 to 1.

function.name: gdk_rgba_to_string
function.description:
Returns a textual specification of @rgba in the form `rgb(r,g,b)` or `rgba(r,g,b,a)`, where “r”, “g”, “b” and “a” represent the red, green, blue and alpha values respectively. “r”, “g”, and “b” are represented as integers in the range 0 to 255, and “a” is represented as a floating point value in the range 0 to 1.
These string forms are string forms that are supported by the CSS3 colors module, and can be parsed by [method@Gdk.RGBA.parse].
Note that this string representation may lose some precision, since “r”, “g” and “b” are represented as 8-bit integers. If this is a concern, you should use a different representation.

function.name: gdk_scroll_event_get_deltas
function.description:
Extracts the scroll deltas of a scroll event.
The deltas will be zero unless the scroll direction is %GDK_SCROLL_SMOOTH.
For the representation unit of these deltas, see [method@Gdk.ScrollEvent.get_unit].

parameter.name: delta_x
parameter.parameter_description: return location for x scroll delta

parameter.name: delta_y
parameter.parameter_description: return location for y scroll delta

function.name: gdk_scroll_event_get_direction
function.description: Extracts the direction of a scroll event.

function.name: gdk_scroll_event_get_unit
function.description:
Extracts the scroll delta unit of a scroll event.
The unit will always be %GDK_SCROLL_UNIT_WHEEL if the scroll direction is not %GDK_SCROLL_SMOOTH.
Since: 4.8

function.name: gdk_scroll_event_is_stop
function.description:
Check whether a scroll event is a stop scroll event.
Scroll sequences with smooth scroll information may provide a stop scroll event once the interaction with the device finishes, e.g. by lifting a finger. This stop scroll event is the signal that a widget may trigger kinetic scrolling based on the current velocity.
Stop scroll events always have a delta of 0/0.
function.return: %TRUE if the event is a scroll stop event

function.name: gdk_seat_get_capabilities
function.description: Returns the capabilities this `GdkSeat` currently has.

function.name: gdk_seat_get_devices
function.description: Returns the devices that match the given capabilities.
function.return: A list of `GdkDevices`. The list must be freed with g_list_free(), the elements are owned by GTK and must not be freed.

function.name: gdk_seat_get_display
function.description: Returns the `GdkDisplay` this seat belongs to.
function.return: a `GdkDisplay`. This object is owned by GTK and must not be freed.

function.name: gdk_seat_get_keyboard
function.description: Returns the device that routes keyboard events.
function.return: a `GdkDevice` with keyboard capabilities. This object is owned by GTK and must not be freed.

function.name: gdk_seat_get_pointer
function.description: Returns the device that routes pointer events.
function.return: a `GdkDevice` with pointer capabilities. This object is owned by GTK and must not be freed.

function.name: gdk_seat_get_tools
function.description: Returns all `GdkDeviceTools` that are known to the application.
function.return: A list of tools. Free with g_list_free().

function.name: gdk_set_allowed_backends
function.description:
Sets a list of backends that GDK should try to use.
This can be useful if your application does not work with certain GDK backends.
By default, GDK tries all included backends.
For example:
```c gdk_set_allowed_backends ("wayland,macos,*"); ```
instructs GDK to try the Wayland backend first, followed by the MacOs backend, and then all others.
If the `GDK_BACKEND` environment variable is set, it determines what backends are tried in what order, while still respecting the set of allowed backends that are specified by this function.
The possible backend names are:
- `broadway` - `macos` - `wayland`. - `win32` - `x11`
You can also include a `*` in the list to try all remaining backends.
This call must happen prior to functions that open a display, such as [func@Gdk.Display.open], `gtk_init()`, or `gtk_init_check()` in order to take effect.

function.name: gdk_surface_beep
function.description:
Emits a short beep associated to @surface.
If the display of @surface does not support per-surface beeps, emits a short beep on the display just as [method@Gdk.Display.beep].

function.name: gdk_surface_create_cairo_context
function.description: Creates a new `GdkCairoContext` for rendering on @surface.

function.name: gdk_surface_create_gl_context
function.description:
Creates a new `GdkGLContext` for the `GdkSurface`.
The context is disconnected from any particular surface or surface. If the creation of the `GdkGLContext` failed, @error will be set. Before using the returned `GdkGLContext`, you will need to call [method@Gdk.GLContext.make_current] or [method@Gdk.GLContext.realize].

function.name: gdk_surface_create_similar_surface
function.description:
Create a new Cairo surface that is as compatible as possible with the given @surface.
For example the new surface will have the same fallback resolution and font options as @surface. Generally, the new surface will also use the same backend as @surface, unless that is not possible for some reason. The type of the returned surface may be examined with cairo_surface_get_type().
Initially the surface contents are all 0 (transparent if contents have transparency, black otherwise.)
This function always returns a valid pointer, but it will return a pointer to a “nil” surface if @other is already in an error state or any other error occurs.
Deprecated: 4.12: Create a suitable cairo image surface yourself

parameter.name: surface
parameter.parameter_description: surface to make new surface similar to

parameter.name: content
parameter.parameter_description: the content for the new surface

function.return: a pointer to the newly allocated surface. The caller owns the surface and should call cairo_surface_destroy() when done with it.

function.name: gdk_surface_create_vulkan_context
function.description:
Sets an error and returns %NULL.
Deprecated: 4.14: GTK does not expose any Vulkan internals. This function is a leftover that was accidentally exposed.

function.name: gdk_surface_destroy
function.description:
Destroys the window system resources associated with @surface and decrements @surface's reference count.
The window system resources for all children of @surface are also destroyed, but the children’s reference counts are not decremented.
Note that a surface will not be destroyed automatically when its reference count reaches zero. You must call this function yourself before that happens.

function.name: gdk_surface_get_cursor
function.description:
Retrieves a `GdkCursor` pointer for the cursor currently set on the `GdkSurface`.
If the return value is %NULL then there is no custom cursor set on the surface, and it is using the cursor for its parent surface.
Use [method@Gdk.Surface.set_cursor] to unset the cursor of the surface.

function.name: gdk_surface_get_device_cursor
function.description:
Retrieves a `GdkCursor` pointer for the @device currently set on the specified `GdkSurface`.
If the return value is %NULL then there is no custom cursor set on the specified surface, and it is using the cursor for its parent surface.
Use [method@Gdk.Surface.set_cursor] to unset the cursor of the surface.

function.name: gdk_surface_get_device_position
function.description:
Obtains the current device position and modifier state.
The position is given in coordinates relative to the upper left corner of @surface.
Return: %TRUE if the device is over the surface

parameter.name: x
parameter.parameter_description: return location for the X coordinate of @device

parameter.name: y
parameter.parameter_description: return location for the Y coordinate of @device

parameter.name: mask
parameter.parameter_description: return location for the modifier mask

function.name: gdk_surface_get_display
function.description: Gets the `GdkDisplay` associated with a `GdkSurface`.

function.name: gdk_surface_get_frame_clock
function.description:
Gets the frame clock for the surface.
The frame clock for a surface never changes unless the surface is reparented to a new toplevel surface.

parameter.name: surface
parameter.parameter_description: surface to get frame clock for

function.name: gdk_surface_get_height
function.description:
Returns the height of the given @surface.
Surface size is reported in ”application pixels”, not ”device pixels” (see [method@Gdk.Surface.get_scale_factor]).

function.name: gdk_surface_get_mapped
function.description:
Checks whether the surface has been mapped.
A surface is mapped with [method@Gdk.Toplevel.present] or [method@Gdk.Popup.present].

function.name: gdk_surface_get_scale
function.description:
Returns the internal scale that maps from surface coordinates to the actual device pixels.
When the scale is bigger than 1, the windowing system prefers to get buffers with a resolution that is bigger than the surface size (e.g. to show the surface on a high-resolution display, or in a magnifier).
Compare with [method@Gdk.Surface.get_scale_factor], which returns the next larger integer.
The scale may change during the lifetime of the surface.
Since: 4.12

function.name: gdk_surface_get_scale_factor
function.description:
Returns the internal scale factor that maps from surface coordinates to the actual device pixels.
On traditional systems this is 1, but on very high density outputs this can be a higher value (often 2). A higher value means that drawing is automatically scaled up to a higher resolution, so any code doing drawing will automatically look nicer. However, if you are supplying pixel-based data the scale value can be used to determine whether to use a pixel resource with higher resolution data.
The scale factor may change during the lifetime of the surface.

parameter.name: surface
parameter.parameter_description: surface to get scale factor for

function.name: gdk_surface_get_width
function.description:
Returns the width of the given @surface.
Surface size is reported in ”application pixels”, not ”device pixels” (see [method@Gdk.Surface.get_scale_factor]).

function.name: gdk_surface_hide
function.description:
Hide the surface.
For toplevel surfaces, withdraws them, so they will no longer be known to the window manager; for all surfaces, unmaps them, so they won’t be displayed. Normally done automatically as part of [gtk_widget_hide()](../gtk4/method.Widget.hide.html).

function.name: gdk_surface_is_destroyed
function.description: Check to see if a surface is destroyed.

function.name: gdk_surface_new_popup
function.description:
Create a new popup surface.
The surface will be attached to @parent and can be positioned relative to it using [method@Gdk.Popup.present].

parameter.name: parent
parameter.parameter_description: the parent surface to attach the surface to

parameter.name: autohide
parameter.parameter_description: whether to hide the surface on outside clicks

function.name: gdk_surface_new_toplevel
function.description: Creates a new toplevel surface.

parameter.name: display
parameter.parameter_description: the display to create the surface on

function.name: gdk_surface_queue_render
function.description:
Forces a [signal@Gdk.Surface::render] signal emission for @surface to be scheduled.
This function is useful for implementations that track invalid regions on their own.

function.name: gdk_surface_request_layout
function.description:
Request a layout phase from the surface's frame clock.
See [method@Gdk.FrameClock.request_phase].

function.name: gdk_surface_set_cursor
function.description:
Sets the default mouse pointer for a `GdkSurface`.
Passing %NULL for the @cursor argument means that @surface will use the cursor of its parent surface. Most surfaces should use this default. Note that @cursor must be for the same display as @surface.
Use [ctor@Gdk.Cursor.new_from_name] or [ctor@Gdk.Cursor.new_from_texture] to create the cursor. To make the cursor invisible, use %GDK_BLANK_CURSOR.

function.name: gdk_surface_set_device_cursor
function.description:
Sets a specific `GdkCursor` for a given device when it gets inside @surface.
Passing %NULL for the @cursor argument means that @surface will use the cursor of its parent surface. Most surfaces should use this default.
Use [ctor@Gdk.Cursor.new_from_name] or [ctor@Gdk.Cursor.new_from_texture] to create the cursor. To make the cursor invisible, use %GDK_BLANK_CURSOR.

function.name: gdk_surface_set_input_region
function.description:
Apply the region to the surface for the purpose of event handling.
Mouse events which happen while the pointer position corresponds to an unset bit in the mask will be passed on the surface below @surface.
An input region is typically used with RGBA surfaces. The alpha channel of the surface defines which pixels are invisible and allows for nicely antialiased borders, and the input region controls where the surface is “clickable”.
Use [method@Gdk.Display.supports_input_shapes] to find out if a particular backend supports input regions.

parameter.name: region
parameter.parameter_description: region of surface to be reactive

function.name: gdk_surface_set_opaque_region
function.description:
Marks a region of the `GdkSurface` as opaque.
For optimisation purposes, compositing window managers may like to not draw obscured regions of surfaces, or turn off blending during for these regions. With RGB windows with no transparency, this is just the shape of the window, but with ARGB32 windows, the compositor does not know what regions of the window are transparent or not.
This function only works for toplevel surfaces.
GTK will update this property automatically if the @surface background is opaque, as we know where the opaque regions are. If your surface background is not opaque, please update this property in your [GtkWidgetClass.css_changed](../gtk4/vfunc.Widget.css_changed.html) handler.
Deprecated: 4.16: GDK can figure out the opaque parts of a window itself by inspecting the contents that are drawn.

parameter.name: region
parameter.parameter_description: a region, or %NULL to make the entire surface opaque

function.name: gdk_surface_translate_coordinates
function.description:
Translates coordinates between two surfaces.
Note that this only works if @to and @from are popups or transient-for to the same toplevel (directly or indirectly).
function.return: %TRUE if the coordinates were successfully translated

function.name: gdk_texture_download
function.description:
Downloads the @texture into local memory.
This may be an expensive operation, as the actual texture data may reside on a GPU or on a remote display server.
The data format of the downloaded data is equivalent to %CAIRO_FORMAT_ARGB32, so every downloaded pixel requires 4 bytes of memory.
Downloading a texture into a Cairo image surface: ```c surface = cairo_image_surface_create (CAIRO_FORMAT_ARGB32, gdk_texture_get_width (texture), gdk_texture_get_height (texture)); gdk_texture_download (texture, cairo_image_surface_get_data (surface), cairo_image_surface_get_stride (surface)); cairo_surface_mark_dirty (surface); ```
For more flexible download capabilities, see [struct@Gdk.TextureDownloader].

parameter.name: data
parameter.parameter_description: pointer to enough memory to be filled with the downloaded data of @texture

function.name: gdk_texture_downloader_copy
function.description:
Creates a copy of the downloader.
This function is meant for language bindings.
Since: 4.10

function.name: gdk_texture_downloader_download_bytes
function.description:
Downloads the given texture pixels into a `GBytes`. The rowstride will be stored in the stride value.
This function will abort if it tries to download a large texture and fails to allocate memory. If you think that may happen, you should handle memory allocation yourself and use [method@Gdk.TextureDownloader.download_into] once allocation succeeded.
Since: 4.10

parameter.name: out_stride
parameter.parameter_description: The stride of the resulting data in bytes

function.name: gdk_texture_downloader_download_into
function.description:
Downloads the @texture into local memory.
Since: 4.10

parameter.name: data
parameter.parameter_description: pointer to enough memory to be filled with the downloaded data of the texture

function.name: gdk_texture_downloader_free
function.description:
Frees the given downloader and all its associated resources.
Since: 4.10

function.name: gdk_texture_downloader_get_color_state
function.description:
Gets the color state that the data will be downloaded in.
Since: 4.16
function.return: The color state of the download

function.name: gdk_texture_downloader_get_format
function.description:
Gets the format that the data will be downloaded in.
Since: 4.10

function.name: gdk_texture_downloader_get_texture
function.description:
Gets the texture that the downloader will download.
Since: 4.10

function.name: gdk_texture_downloader_new
function.description:
Creates a new texture downloader for @texture.
By default, the downloader will convert the data to the default memory format, and to the sRGB color state.
Since: 4.10

function.name: gdk_texture_downloader_set_color_state
function.description:
Sets the color state the downloader will convert the data to.
By default, the sRGB colorstate returned by [func@ColorState.get_srgb] is used.
Since: 4.16

function.name: gdk_texture_downloader_set_format
function.description:
Sets the format the downloader will download.
By default, GDK_MEMORY_DEFAULT is set.
Since: 4.10

function.name: gdk_texture_downloader_set_texture
function.description:
Changes the texture the downloader will download.
Since: 4.10

function.name: gdk_texture_error_quark
function.description: Registers an error quark for [class@Gdk.Texture] errors.

function.name: gdk_texture_get_color_state
function.description:
Returns the color state associated with the texture.
Since: 4.16

function.name: gdk_texture_get_format
function.description:
Gets the memory format most closely associated with the data of the texture.
Note that it may not be an exact match for texture data stored on the GPU or with compression.
The format can give an indication about the bit depth and opacity of the texture and is useful to determine the best format for downloading the texture.
Since: 4.10
function.return: the preferred format for the texture's data

function.name: gdk_texture_get_height
function.description: Returns the height of the @texture, in pixels.

function.name: gdk_texture_get_width
function.description: Returns the width of @texture, in pixels.

function.name: gdk_texture_new_for_pixbuf
function.description:
Creates a new texture object representing the `GdkPixbuf`.
This function is threadsafe, so that you can e.g. use GTask and [method@Gio.Task.run_in_thread] to avoid blocking the main thread while loading a big image.

function.name: gdk_texture_new_from_bytes
function.description:
Creates a new texture by loading an image from memory,
The file format is detected automatically. The supported formats are PNG, JPEG and TIFF, though more formats might be available.
If %NULL is returned, then @error will be set.
This function is threadsafe, so that you can e.g. use GTask and [method@Gio.Task.run_in_thread] to avoid blocking the main thread while loading a big image.
Since: 4.6

parameter.name: bytes
parameter.parameter_description: a `GBytes` containing the data to load

function.name: gdk_texture_new_from_file
function.description:
Creates a new texture by loading an image from a file.
The file format is detected automatically. The supported formats are PNG, JPEG and TIFF, though more formats might be available.
If %NULL is returned, then @error will be set.
This function is threadsafe, so that you can e.g. use GTask and [method@Gio.Task.run_in_thread] to avoid blocking the main thread while loading a big image.

function.name: gdk_texture_new_from_filename
function.description:
Creates a new texture by loading an image from a file.
The file format is detected automatically. The supported formats are PNG, JPEG and TIFF, though more formats might be available.
If %NULL is returned, then @error will be set.
This function is threadsafe, so that you can e.g. use GTask and [method@Gio.Task.run_in_thread] to avoid blocking the main thread while loading a big image.
Since: 4.6

function.name: gdk_texture_new_from_resource
function.description:
Creates a new texture by loading an image from a resource.
The file format is detected automatically. The supported formats are PNG and JPEG, though more formats might be available.
It is a fatal error if @resource_path does not specify a valid image resource and the program will abort if that happens. If you are unsure about the validity of a resource, use [ctor@Gdk.Texture.new_from_file] to load it.
This function is threadsafe, so that you can e.g. use GTask and [method@Gio.Task.run_in_thread] to avoid blocking the main thread while loading a big image.

parameter.name: resource_path
parameter.parameter_description: the path of the resource file

function.name: gdk_texture_save_to_png
function.description:
Store the given @texture to the @filename as a PNG file.
This is a utility function intended for debugging and testing. If you want more control over formats, proper error handling or want to store to a [iface@Gio.File] or other location, you might want to use [method@Gdk.Texture.save_to_png_bytes] or look into the gdk-pixbuf library.

function.name: gdk_texture_save_to_png_bytes
function.description:
Store the given @texture in memory as a PNG file.
Use [ctor@Gdk.Texture.new_from_bytes] to read it back.
If you want to serialize a texture, this is a convenient and portable way to do that.
If you need more control over the generated image, such as attaching metadata, you should look into an image handling library such as the gdk-pixbuf library.
If you are dealing with high dynamic range float data, you might also want to consider [method@Gdk.Texture.save_to_tiff_bytes] instead.
Since: 4.6
function.return: a newly allocated `GBytes` containing PNG data

function.name: gdk_texture_save_to_tiff
function.description:
Store the given @texture to the @filename as a TIFF file.
GTK will attempt to store data without loss. Since: 4.6

function.name: gdk_texture_save_to_tiff_bytes
function.description:
Store the given @texture in memory as a TIFF file.
Use [ctor@Gdk.Texture.new_from_bytes] to read it back.
This function is intended to store a representation of the texture's data that is as accurate as possible. This is particularly relevant when working with high dynamic range images and floating-point texture data.
If that is not your concern and you are interested in a smaller size and a more portable format, you might want to use [method@Gdk.Texture.save_to_png_bytes].
Since: 4.6
function.return: a newly allocated `GBytes` containing TIFF data

function.name: gdk_toplevel_begin_move
function.description:
Begins an interactive move operation.
You might use this function to implement draggable titlebars.

parameter.name: device
parameter.parameter_description: the device used for the operation

parameter.name: button
parameter.parameter_description: the button being used to drag, or 0 for a keyboard-initiated drag

parameter.name: x
parameter.parameter_description: surface X coordinate of mouse click that began the drag

parameter.name: y
parameter.parameter_description: surface Y coordinate of mouse click that began the drag

parameter.name: timestamp
parameter.parameter_description: timestamp of mouse click that began the drag (use [method@Gdk.Event.get_time])

function.name: gdk_toplevel_begin_resize
function.description:
Begins an interactive resize operation.
You might use this function to implement a “window resize grip.”

parameter.name: edge
parameter.parameter_description: the edge or corner from which the drag is started

parameter.name: device
parameter.parameter_description: the device used for the operation

parameter.name: button
parameter.parameter_description: the button being used to drag, or 0 for a keyboard-initiated drag

parameter.name: x
parameter.parameter_description: surface X coordinate of mouse click that began the drag

parameter.name: y
parameter.parameter_description: surface Y coordinate of mouse click that began the drag

parameter.name: timestamp
parameter.parameter_description: timestamp of mouse click that began the drag (use [method@Gdk.Event.get_time])

function.name: gdk_toplevel_focus
function.description:
Sets keyboard focus to @surface.
In most cases, [gtk_window_present_with_time()](../gtk4/method.Window.present_with_time.html) should be used on a [GtkWindow](../gtk4/class.Window.html), rather than calling this function.

parameter.name: timestamp
parameter.parameter_description: timestamp of the event triggering the surface focus

function.name: gdk_toplevel_get_state
function.description: Gets the bitwise or of the currently active surface state flags, from the `GdkToplevelState` enumeration.

function.name: gdk_toplevel_inhibit_system_shortcuts
function.description:
Requests that the @toplevel inhibit the system shortcuts.
This is asking the desktop environment/windowing system to let all keyboard events reach the surface, as long as it is focused, instead of triggering system actions.
If granted, the rerouting remains active until the default shortcuts processing is restored with [method@Gdk.Toplevel.restore_system_shortcuts], or the request is revoked by the desktop environment, windowing system or the user.
A typical use case for this API is remote desktop or virtual machine viewers which need to inhibit the default system keyboard shortcuts so that the remote session or virtual host gets those instead of the local environment.
The windowing system or desktop environment may ask the user to grant or deny the request or even choose to ignore the request entirely.
The caller can be notified whenever the request is granted or revoked by listening to the [property@Gdk.Toplevel:shortcuts-inhibited] property.

parameter.name: event
parameter.parameter_description: the `GdkEvent` that is triggering the inhibit request, or %NULL if none is available

function.name: gdk_toplevel_layout_copy
function.description: Create a new `GdkToplevelLayout` and copy the contents of @layout into it.

function.name: gdk_toplevel_layout_equal
function.description: Check whether @layout and @other has identical layout properties.
function.return: %TRUE if @layout and @other have identical layout properties, otherwise %FALSE.

function.name: gdk_toplevel_layout_get_fullscreen
function.description: If the layout specifies whether to the toplevel should go fullscreen, the value pointed to by @fullscreen is set to %TRUE if it should go fullscreen, or %FALSE, if it should go unfullscreen.

parameter.name: fullscreen
parameter.parameter_description: location to store whether the toplevel should be fullscreen

function.return: whether the @layout specifies the fullscreen state for the toplevel

function.name: gdk_toplevel_layout_get_fullscreen_monitor
function.description: Returns the monitor that the layout is fullscreening the surface on.

function.name: gdk_toplevel_layout_get_maximized
function.description: If the layout specifies whether to the toplevel should go maximized, the value pointed to by @maximized is set to %TRUE if it should go fullscreen, or %FALSE, if it should go unmaximized.

parameter.name: maximized
parameter.parameter_description: set to %TRUE if the toplevel should be maximized

function.return: whether the @layout specifies the maximized state for the toplevel

function.name: gdk_toplevel_layout_get_resizable
function.description: Returns whether the layout should allow the user to resize the surface.

function.name: gdk_toplevel_layout_new
function.description:
Create a toplevel layout description.
Used together with gdk_toplevel_present() to describe how a toplevel surface should be placed and behave on-screen.
The size is in ”application pixels”, not ”device pixels” (see gdk_surface_get_scale_factor()).

function.name: gdk_toplevel_layout_ref
function.description: Increases the reference count of @layout.

function.name: gdk_toplevel_layout_set_fullscreen
function.description: Sets whether the layout should cause the surface to be fullscreen when presented.

function.name: gdk_toplevel_layout_set_maximized
function.description: Sets whether the layout should cause the surface to be maximized when presented.

function.name: gdk_toplevel_layout_set_resizable
function.description: Sets whether the layout should allow the user to resize the surface after it has been presented.

function.name: gdk_toplevel_layout_unref
function.description: Decreases the reference count of @layout.

function.name: gdk_toplevel_lower
function.description:
Asks to lower the @toplevel below other windows.
The windowing system may choose to ignore the request.

function.name: gdk_toplevel_minimize
function.description:
Asks to minimize the @toplevel.
The windowing system may choose to ignore the request.

function.name: gdk_toplevel_present
function.description:
Present @toplevel after having processed the `GdkToplevelLayout` rules.
If the toplevel was previously not showing, it will be showed, otherwise it will change layout according to @layout.
GDK may emit the [signal@Gdk.Toplevel::compute-size] signal to let the user of this toplevel compute the preferred size of the toplevel surface.
Presenting is asynchronous and the specified layout parameters are not guaranteed to be respected.

function.name: gdk_toplevel_restore_system_shortcuts
function.description:
Restore default system keyboard shortcuts which were previously inhibited.
This undoes the effect of [method@Gdk.Toplevel.inhibit_system_shortcuts].

function.name: gdk_toplevel_set_decorated
function.description:
Sets the toplevel to be decorated.
Setting @decorated to %FALSE hints the desktop environment that the surface has its own, client-side decorations and does not need to have window decorations added.

function.name: gdk_toplevel_set_deletable
function.description:
Sets the toplevel to be deletable.
Setting @deletable to %TRUE hints the desktop environment that it should offer the user a way to close the surface.

function.name: gdk_toplevel_set_icon_list
function.description:
Sets a list of icons for the surface.
One of these will be used to represent the surface in iconic form. The icon may be shown in window lists or task bars. Which icon size is shown depends on the window manager. The window manager can scale the icon but setting several size icons can give better image quality.
Note that some platforms don't support surface icons.

parameter.name: surfaces
parameter.parameter_description: A list of textures to use as icon, of different sizes

function.name: gdk_toplevel_set_modal
function.description:
Sets the toplevel to be modal.
The application can use this hint to tell the window manager that a certain surface has modal behaviour. The window manager can use this information to handle modal surfaces in a special way.
You should only use this on surfaces for which you have previously called [method@Gdk.Toplevel.set_transient_for].

parameter.name: modal
parameter.parameter_description: %TRUE if the surface is modal, %FALSE otherwise.

function.name: gdk_toplevel_set_startup_id
function.description:
Sets the startup notification ID.
When using GTK, typically you should use [gtk_window_set_startup_id()](../gtk4/method.Window.set_startup_id.html) instead of this low-level function.

function.name: gdk_toplevel_set_title
function.description:
Sets the title of a toplevel surface.
The title maybe be displayed in the titlebar, in lists of windows, etc.

function.name: gdk_toplevel_set_transient_for
function.description:
Sets a transient-for parent.
Indicates to the window manager that @surface is a transient dialog associated with the application surface @parent. This allows the window manager to do things like center @surface on @parent and keep @surface above @parent.
See [gtk_window_set_transient_for()](../gtk4/method.Window.set_transient_for.html) if you’re using [GtkWindow](../gtk4/class.Window.html).

function.name: gdk_toplevel_show_window_menu
function.description:
Asks the windowing system to show the window menu.
The window menu is the menu shown when right-clicking the titlebar on traditional windows managed by the window manager. This is useful for windows using client-side decorations, activating it with a right-click on the window decorations.

parameter.name: event
parameter.parameter_description: a `GdkEvent` to show the menu for

function.return: %TRUE if the window menu was shown and %FALSE otherwise.

function.name: gdk_toplevel_size_get_bounds
function.description:
Retrieves the bounds the toplevel is placed within.
The bounds represent the largest size a toplevel may have while still being able to fit within some type of boundary. Depending on the backend, this may be equivalent to the dimensions of the work area or the monitor on which the window is being presented on, or something else that limits the way a toplevel can be presented.

function.name: gdk_toplevel_size_set_min_size
function.description:
Sets the minimum size of the toplevel.
The minimum size corresponds to the limitations the toplevel can be shrunk to, without resulting in incorrect painting. A user of a `GdkToplevel` should calculate these given both the existing size, and the bounds retrieved from the `GdkToplevelSize` object.
The minimum size should be within the bounds (see [method@Gdk.ToplevelSize.get_bounds]).

function.name: gdk_toplevel_size_set_shadow_width
function.description:
Sets the shadows size of the toplevel.
The shadow width corresponds to the part of the computed surface size that would consist of the shadow margin surrounding the window, would there be any.
Shadow width should only be set if [method@Gtk.Display.supports_shadow_width] is %TRUE.

parameter.name: left
parameter.parameter_description: width of the left part of the shadow

parameter.name: right
parameter.parameter_description: width of the right part of the shadow

parameter.name: top
parameter.parameter_description: height of the top part of the shadow

parameter.name: bottom
parameter.parameter_description: height of the bottom part of the shadow

function.name: gdk_toplevel_size_set_size
function.description:
Sets the size the toplevel prefers to be resized to.
The size should be within the bounds (see [method@Gdk.ToplevelSize.get_bounds]). The set size should be considered as a hint, and should not be assumed to be respected by the windowing system, or backend.

function.name: gdk_toplevel_supports_edge_constraints
function.description: Returns whether the desktop environment supports tiled window states.
function.return: %TRUE if the desktop environment supports tiled window states

function.name: gdk_toplevel_titlebar_gesture
function.description:
Performs a title bar gesture.
Since: 4.4

function.name: gdk_touch_event_get_emulating_pointer
function.description: Extracts whether a touch event is emulating a pointer event.

function.name: gdk_touchpad_event_get_deltas
function.description: Extracts delta information from a touchpad event.

function.name: gdk_touchpad_event_get_gesture_phase
function.description: Extracts the touchpad gesture phase from a touchpad event.

function.name: gdk_touchpad_event_get_n_fingers
function.description: Extracts the number of fingers from a touchpad event.

function.name: gdk_touchpad_event_get_pinch_angle_delta
function.description: Extracts the angle delta from a touchpad pinch event.

function.name: gdk_touchpad_event_get_pinch_scale
function.description: Extracts the scale from a touchpad pinch event.

function.name: gdk_unicode_to_keyval
function.description: Convert from a Unicode character to a key symbol.
function.return: the corresponding GDK key symbol, if one exists. or, if there is no corresponding symbol, wc | 0x01000000

function.name: gdk_vulkan_context_get_device
function.description: Gets the Vulkan device that this context is using.

function.name: gdk_vulkan_context_get_draw_index
function.description:
Gets the index of the image that is currently being drawn.
This function can only be used between [method@Gdk.DrawContext.begin_frame] and [method@Gdk.DrawContext.end_frame] calls.
function.return: the index of the images that is being drawn

function.name: gdk_vulkan_context_get_image
function.description: Gets the image with index @id that this context is using.

parameter.name: id
parameter.parameter_description: the index of the image to return

function.name: gdk_vulkan_context_get_image_format
function.description: Gets the image format that this context is using.

function.name: gdk_vulkan_context_get_instance
function.description: Gets the Vulkan instance that is associated with @context.

function.name: gdk_vulkan_context_get_n_images
function.description: Gets the number of images that this context is using in its swap chain.

function.name: gdk_vulkan_context_get_physical_device
function.description: Gets the Vulkan physical device that this context is using.

function.name: gdk_vulkan_context_get_queue
function.description: Gets the Vulkan queue that this context is using.

function.name: gdk_vulkan_context_get_queue_family_index
function.description:
Gets the family index for the queue that this context is using.
See vkGetPhysicalDeviceQueueFamilyProperties().

function.name: gdk_vulkan_context_set_draw_semaphore
function.description:
Sets the Vulkan semaphore that will be used in the immediately following gdk_draw_context_begin_frame() call. This is essentially an extra argument for that call, but without extending the arguments of that generic function with Vulkan-specific things.
This function must be called or begin_frame() will abort.

function.name: gdk_vulkan_error_quark
function.description: Registers an error quark for [class@Gdk.VulkanContext] errors.

function.name: graphene_box2d_alloc
function.description:
Allocates a new #graphene_box2d_t.
The contents of the returned structure are undefined.
Since: 1.12
function.return: the newly allocated #graphene_box2d_t structure. Use graphene_box2d_free() to free the resources allocated by this function

function.name: graphene_box2d_contains_box
function.description:
Checks whether the #graphene_box2d_t @a contains the given #graphene_box2d_t @b.
Since: 1.12
function.return: `true` if the box is contained in the given box

function.name: graphene_box2d_contains_point
function.description:
Checks whether @box contains the given @point.
Since: 1.12
function.return: `true` if the point is contained in the given box

function.name: graphene_box2d_contains_rect
function.description:
Checks whether @box contains the given @rect.
Since: 1.12
function.return: `true` if the rectangle is contained in the given box

function.name: graphene_box2d_empty
function.description:
A degenerate #graphene_box2d_t that can only be expanded.
The returned value is owned by Graphene and should not be modified or freed.
Since: 1.12

function.name: graphene_box2d_equal
function.description:
Checks whether the two given boxes are equal.
Since: 1.12

function.name: graphene_box2d_expand
function.description:
Expands the dimensions of @box to include the coordinates at @point.
Since: 1.12

parameter.name: point
parameter.parameter_description: the coordinates of the point to include

parameter.name: res
parameter.parameter_description: return location for the expanded box

function.name: graphene_box2d_expand_scalar
function.description:
Expands the dimensions of @box by the given @scalar value.
If @scalar is positive, the #graphene_box2d_t will grow; if @scalar is negative, the #graphene_box2d_t will shrink.
Since: 1.12

parameter.name: res
parameter.parameter_description: return location for the expanded box

function.name: graphene_box2d_expand_vec2
function.description:
Expands the dimensions of @box to include the coordinates of the given vector.
Since: 1.12

parameter.name: vec
parameter.parameter_description: the coordinates of the point to include, as a #graphene_vec2_t

parameter.name: res
parameter.parameter_description: return location for the expanded box

function.name: graphene_box2d_free
function.description:
Frees the resources allocated by graphene_box2d_alloc().
Since: 1.12

function.name: graphene_box2d_get_center
function.description:
Retrieves the coordinates of the center of a #graphene_box2d_t.
Since: 1.12

parameter.name: center
parameter.parameter_description: return location for the coordinates of the center

function.name: graphene_box2d_get_height
function.description:
Retrieves the size of the @box on the Y axis.
Since: 1.12

function.name: graphene_box2d_get_max
function.description:
Retrieves the coordinates of the maximum point of the given #graphene_box2d_t.
Since: 1.12

parameter.name: max
parameter.parameter_description: return location for the maximum point

function.name: graphene_box2d_get_min
function.description:
Retrieves the coordinates of the minimum point of the given #graphene_box2d_t.
Since: 1.12

parameter.name: min
parameter.parameter_description: return location for the minimum point

function.name: graphene_box2d_get_minmax
function.description:
Retrieves the coordinates of the minimum and maximum points of the given #graphene_box2d_t.
Since: 1.12

parameter.name: min
parameter.parameter_description: return location for the minimum point

parameter.name: max
parameter.parameter_description: return location for the maximum point

function.name: graphene_box2d_get_size
function.description:
Retrieves the size of the box on all three axes, and stores it into the given @size vector.
Since: 1.12

function.name: graphene_box2d_get_vertices
function.description:
Computes the vertices of the given #graphene_box2d_t.
Since: 1.12

parameter.name: vertices
parameter.parameter_description: return location for an array of 4 #graphene_vec2_t

function.name: graphene_box2d_get_width
function.description:
Retrieves the size of the @box on the X axis.
Since: 1.12

function.name: graphene_box2d_infinite
function.description:
A degenerate #graphene_box2d_t that cannot be expanded.
The returned value is owned by Graphene and should not be modified or freed.
Since: 1.12

function.name: graphene_box2d_init
function.description:
Initializes the given #graphene_box2d_t with two vertices.
Since: 1.12

parameter.name: min
parameter.parameter_description: the coordinates of the minimum vertex

parameter.name: max
parameter.parameter_description: the coordinates of the maximum vertex

function.name: graphene_box2d_init_from_box
function.description:
Initializes the given #graphene_box2d_t with the vertices of another #graphene_box2d_t.
Since: 1.12

function.name: graphene_box2d_init_from_points
function.description:
Initializes the given #graphene_box2d_t with the given array of vertices.
If @n_points is 0, the returned box is initialized with graphene_box2d_empty().
Since: 1.12

function.name: graphene_box2d_init_from_rect
function.description:
Initializes the given #graphene_box2d_t with the origin and size of a #graphene_rect_t.
Since: 1.12

function.name: graphene_box2d_init_from_vec2
function.description:
Initializes the given #graphene_box2d_t with two vertices stored inside #graphene_vec2_t.
Since: 1.12

parameter.name: min
parameter.parameter_description: the coordinates of the minimum vertex

parameter.name: max
parameter.parameter_description: the coordinates of the maximum vertex

function.name: graphene_box2d_init_from_vectors
function.description:
Initializes the given #graphene_box2d_t with the given array of vertices.
If @n_vectors is 0, the returned box is initialized with graphene_box2d_empty().
Since: 1.12

function.name: graphene_box2d_intersection
function.description:
Intersects the two given #graphene_box2d_t.
If the two boxes do not intersect, @res will contain a degenerate box initialized with graphene_box2d_empty().
Since: 1.12
function.return: true if the two boxes intersect

function.name: graphene_box2d_intersects
function.description:
Checks whether two boxes intersect.
See also: graphene_box2d_intersection()
Since: 1.12
function.return: true if the boxes intersect, and false otherwise

function.name: graphene_box2d_minus_one
function.description:
A #graphene_box2d_t with the minimum vertex set at (-1, -1) and the maximum vertex set at (0, 0).
The returned value is owned by Graphene and should not be modified or freed.
Since: 1.12

function.name: graphene_box2d_one
function.description:
A #graphene_box2d_t with the minimum vertex set at (0, 0) and the maximum vertex set at (1, 1).
The returned value is owned by Graphene and should not be modified or freed.
Since: 1.12

function.name: graphene_box2d_one_minus_one
function.description:
A #graphene_box2d_t with the minimum vertex set at (-1, -1) and the maximum vertex set at (1, 1).
The returned value is owned by Graphene and should not be modified or freed.
Since: 1.12

function.name: graphene_box2d_scale_offset
function.description:
Applies a scale and an offset to the vertices of the given box.
If @scale is %NULL, the box will be scaled by (1.0, 1.0).
If @offset is %NULL, the box will be offset by (0.0, 0.0).
Since: 1.12

parameter.name: scale
parameter.parameter_description: a vector with two scaling factors to be applied to the box

parameter.name: offset
parameter.parameter_description: the offset to apply to the box

function.name: graphene_box2d_to_float
function.description:
Stores the minimum and maximum vertices of the given #graphene_box2d_t into an array.
The array layout is:
- min_x - min_y - max_x - max_y
Since: 1.12

parameter.name: v
parameter.parameter_description: return location for an array of floating point values with at least 4 elements

function.name: graphene_box2d_to_rect
function.description:
Stores the minimum and maximum vertices of the given #graphene_box2d_t into a rectangle of equivalent origin and size.
Since: 1.12

function.name: graphene_box2d_union
function.description:
Unions the two given #graphene_box2d_t.
Since: 1.12

function.name: graphene_box2d_zero
function.description:
A #graphene_box2d_t with both the minimum and maximum vertices set at (0, 0).
The returned value is owned by Graphene and should not be modified or freed.
Since: 1.12

function.name: graphene_box_alloc
function.description:
Allocates a new #graphene_box_t.
The contents of the returned structure are undefined.
Since: 1.2
function.return: the newly allocated #graphene_box_t structure. Use graphene_box_free() to free the resources allocated by this function

function.name: graphene_box_contains_box
function.description:
Checks whether the #graphene_box_t @a contains the given #graphene_box_t @b.
Since: 1.2
function.return: `true` if the box is contained in the given box

function.name: graphene_box_contains_point
function.description:
Checks whether @box contains the given @point.
Since: 1.2
function.return: `true` if the point is contained in the given box

function.name: graphene_box_empty
function.description:
A degenerate #graphene_box_t that can only be expanded.
The returned value is owned by Graphene and should not be modified or freed.
Since: 1.2

function.name: graphene_box_equal
function.description:
Checks whether the two given boxes are equal.
Since: 1.2

function.name: graphene_box_expand
function.description:
Expands the dimensions of @box to include the coordinates at @point.
Since: 1.2

parameter.name: point
parameter.parameter_description: the coordinates of the point to include

parameter.name: res
parameter.parameter_description: return location for the expanded box

function.name: graphene_box_expand_scalar
function.description:
Expands the dimensions of @box by the given @scalar value.
If @scalar is positive, the #graphene_box_t will grow; if @scalar is negative, the #graphene_box_t will shrink.
Since: 1.2

parameter.name: res
parameter.parameter_description: return location for the expanded box

function.name: graphene_box_expand_vec3
function.description:
Expands the dimensions of @box to include the coordinates of the given vector.
Since: 1.2

parameter.name: vec
parameter.parameter_description: the coordinates of the point to include, as a #graphene_vec3_t

parameter.name: res
parameter.parameter_description: return location for the expanded box

function.name: graphene_box_free
function.description:
Frees the resources allocated by graphene_box_alloc().
Since: 1.2

function.name: graphene_box_get_bounding_sphere
function.description:
Computes the bounding #graphene_sphere_t capable of containing the given #graphene_box_t.
Since: 1.2

parameter.name: sphere
parameter.parameter_description: return location for the bounding sphere

function.name: graphene_box_get_center
function.description:
Retrieves the coordinates of the center of a #graphene_box_t.
Since: 1.2

parameter.name: center
parameter.parameter_description: return location for the coordinates of the center

function.name: graphene_box_get_depth
function.description:
Retrieves the size of the @box on the Z axis.
Since: 1.2

function.name: graphene_box_get_height
function.description:
Retrieves the size of the @box on the Y axis.
Since: 1.2

function.name: graphene_box_get_max
function.description:
Retrieves the coordinates of the maximum point of the given #graphene_box_t.
Since: 1.2

parameter.name: max
parameter.parameter_description: return location for the maximum point

function.name: graphene_box_get_min
function.description:
Retrieves the coordinates of the minimum point of the given #graphene_box_t.
Since: 1.2

parameter.name: min

Since: 1.10

function.name: graphene_euler_get_order
function.description:
Retrieves the order used to apply the rotations described in the #graphene_euler_t structure, when converting to and from other structures, like #graphene_quaternion_t and #graphene_matrix_t.
This function does not return the %GRAPHENE_EULER_ORDER_DEFAULT enumeration value; it will return the effective order of rotation instead.
Since: 1.2
function.return: the order used to apply the rotations

function.name: graphene_euler_get_x
function.description:
Retrieves the rotation angle on the X axis, in degrees.
Since: 1.2

function.description:
Retrieves the rotation angle on the Y axis, in degrees.
Since: 1.2

function.name: graphene_euler_get_z
function.description:
Retrieves the rotation angle on the Z axis, in degrees.
Since: 1.2

function.name: graphene_euler_init
function.description:
Initializes a #graphene_euler_t using the given angles.
The order of the rotations is %GRAPHENE_EULER_ORDER_DEFAULT.
Since: 1.2

parameter.name: x
parameter.parameter_description: rotation angle on the X axis, in degrees

parameter.name: y
parameter.parameter_description: rotation angle on the Y axis, in degrees

parameter.name: z
parameter.parameter_description: rotation angle on the Z axis, in degrees

function.name: graphene_euler_init_from_euler
function.description:
Initializes a #graphene_euler_t using the angles and order of another #graphene_euler_t.
If the #graphene_euler_t @src is %NULL, this function is equivalent to calling graphene_euler_init() with all angles set to 0.
Since: 1.2

function.name: graphene_euler_init_from_matrix
function.description:
Initializes a #graphene_euler_t using the given rotation matrix.
If the #graphene_matrix_t @m is %NULL, the #graphene_euler_t will be initialized with all angles set to 0.
Since: 1.2

parameter.name: order
parameter.parameter_description: the order used to apply the rotations

function.name: graphene_euler_init_from_quaternion
function.description:
Initializes a #graphene_euler_t using the given normalized quaternion.
If the #graphene_quaternion_t @q is %NULL, the #graphene_euler_t will be initialized with all angles set to 0.
Since: 1.2

parameter.name: order
parameter.parameter_description: the order used to apply the rotations

function.name: graphene_euler_init_from_radians
function.description:
Initializes a #graphene_euler_t using the given angles and order of rotation.
Since: 1.10

parameter.name: x
parameter.parameter_description: rotation angle on the X axis, in radians

parameter.name: y
parameter.parameter_description: rotation angle on the Y axis, in radians

parameter.name: z
parameter.parameter_description: rotation angle on the Z axis, in radians

function.name: graphene_euler_init_from_vec3
function.description:
Initializes a #graphene_euler_t using the angles contained in a #graphene_vec3_t.
If the #graphene_vec3_t @v is %NULL, the #graphene_euler_t will be initialized with all angles set to 0.
Since: 1.2

parameter.name: v
parameter.parameter_description: a #graphene_vec3_t containing the rotation angles in degrees

parameter.name: order

function.name: graphene_euler_init_with_order

Initializes a #graphene_euler_t with the given angles and @order.

parameter.name: y
parameter.parameter_description: rotation angle on the Y axis, in degrees

parameter.name: z
parameter.parameter_description: rotation angle on the Z axis, in degrees

parameter.name: order
parameter.parameter_description: the order used to apply the rotations

function.name: graphene_euler_reorder
function.description:
Reorders a #graphene_euler_t using @order.
This function is equivalent to creating a #graphene_quaternion_t from the given #graphene_euler_t, and then converting the quaternion into another #graphene_euler_t.
Since: 1.2

function.name: graphene_euler_to_matrix
function.description:
Converts a #graphene_euler_t into a transformation matrix expressing the extrinsic composition of rotations described by the Euler angles.
The rotations are applied over the reference frame axes in the order associated with the #graphene_euler_t; for instance, if the order used to initialize @e is %GRAPHENE_EULER_ORDER_XYZ:
* the first rotation moves the body around the X axis with an angle φ * the second rotation moves the body around the Y axis with an angle of ϑ * the third rotation moves the body around the Z axis with an angle of ψ
The rotation sign convention is right-handed, to preserve compatibility between Euler-based, quaternion-based, and angle-axis-based rotations.
Since: 1.2

function.name: graphene_euler_to_quaternion
function.description:
Converts a #graphene_euler_t into a #graphene_quaternion_t.
Since: 1.10

function.name: graphene_euler_to_vec3
function.description:
Retrieves the angles of a #graphene_euler_t and initializes a #graphene_vec3_t with them.
Since: 1.2

function.name: graphene_matrix_decompose
function.description:
Decomposes a transformation matrix into its component transformations.
The algorithm for decomposing a matrix is taken from the [CSS3 Transforms specification](http://dev.w3.org/csswg/css-transforms/); specifically, the decomposition code is based on the equivalent code published in "Graphics Gems II", edited by Jim Arvo, and [available online](http://web.archive.org/web/20150512160205/http://tog.acm.org/resources/GraphicsGems/gemsii/unmatrix.c).
function.return: `true` if the matrix could be decomposed

function.description:

Since: 1.0

Initializes a #graphene_matrix_t from the values of an affine transformation matrix.
The arguments map to the following matrix layout:
|[<!-- language="plain" --> ⎛ xx yx ⎞ ⎛ a b 0 ⎞ ⎜ xy yy ⎟ = ⎜ c d 0 ⎟ ⎝ x0 y0 ⎠ ⎝ tx ty 1 ⎠ ]|

function.name: graphene_matrix_init_identity
function.description:
Initializes a #graphene_matrix_t with the identity matrix.
Since: 1.0

function.name: graphene_matrix_init_look_at
function.description:
Initializes a #graphene_matrix_t so that it positions the "camera" at the given @eye coordinates towards an object at the @center coordinates. The top of the camera is aligned to the direction of the @up vector.
Before the transform, the camera is assumed to be placed at the origin, looking towards the negative Z axis, with the top side of the camera facing in the direction of the Y axis and the right side in the direction of the X axis.
In theory, one could use @m to transform a model of such a camera into world-space. However, it is more common to use the inverse of @m to transform another object from world coordinates to the view coordinates of the camera. Typically you would then apply the camera projection transform to get from view to screen coordinates.
Since: 1.0

parameter.name: eye
parameter.parameter_description: the vector describing the position to look from

parameter.name: center
parameter.parameter_description: the vector describing the position to look at

parameter.name: up
parameter.parameter_description: the vector describing the world's upward direction; usually, this is the graphene_vec3_y_axis() vector

Initializes a #graphene_matrix_t with an orthographic projection.

parameter.name: bottom

parameter.name: z_near

parameter.name: z_far

parameter.name: factor_z

function.name: graphene_matrix_to_2d
function.description:
Converts a #graphene_matrix_t to an affine transformation matrix, if the given matrix is compatible.
The returned values have the following layout:
|[<!-- language="plain" --> ⎛ xx yx ⎞ ⎛ a b 0 ⎞ ⎜ xy yy ⎟ = ⎜ c d 0 ⎟ ⎝ x0 y0 ⎠ ⎝ tx ty 1 ⎠ ]|
This function can be used to convert between a #graphene_matrix_t and an affine matrix type from other libraries.

parameter.name: yx
parameter.parameter_description: return location for the yx member

parameter.name: xy
parameter.parameter_description: return location for the xy member

parameter.parameter_description: return location for the yy member

parameter.name: x_0
parameter.parameter_description: return location for the x0 member

parameter.name: y_0

function.return: `true` if the matrix is compatible with an affine transformation matrix

function.description:
Transforms each corner of a #graphene_rect_t using the given matrix @m.
The result is the axis aligned bounding rectangle containing the coplanar quadrilateral.
See also: graphene_matrix_transform_point()
